Here's a lesson Hollywood needs to learn about comic book movies and fast: just because there are hundreds of heroes doesn't mean that every one of them has to show up on film in the next three years or so.
Ghosts of Girlfriends Past might be one of the most unoriginal films ever made, but it works anyway.
Don't worry this time around, our pop culture is in good hands.
Really, I Love You, Man is a wonderfully clever romantic comedy, it just happens that the love is platonic and between two guys.
The film is a wonderful piece of cinematic fluff sure to keep your eyes locked on the screen and your head at least partially interested.

It's a slice of American life just like Mendes delivered in American Beauty, Revolutionary Road and, to a lesser extent, the heavily underrated Road to Perdition -- except now he's done it with a bunch of comedians and a bit less depr
The Proposal gives some hope that the rom-com can still function.
This is Jack Black and Michael Cera doing Jack Black and Michael Cera, the problem is that that was funny about three years ago and now it's just kind of predictable and boring.
The first film was a summer action movie masterpiece, this one can't even make giant, transforming robots stay interesting for its entire running time.

You desperately want to be grabbed and taken along for what should be one of the most exciting "true stories" in history, but instead you're stuck wondering why actors as good as Depp and Bale aren't able to make their characters come to life and a direct
Some of the scenes do beg the question of if they were staged or not, but after the first ten minutes or so you're laughing too hard to really care.
(500) Days of Summer is that rare movie about boy meets girl that defeats the oldest nemesis of the rom-com genre: predictability
It's hard to know where to start with what the film does right, since almost everything in the movie is horrortastic.
So yes, Half-Blood Prince is a bloody good time, and the best summer blockbuster film since Star Trek, but make sure you make the time to sit down and read the books if you haven't.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Duplicity, when it comes down to it, is wonderful simplicity.
Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li is not the movie Street Fighter fans have been clamoring for, but that is mostly because Street Fighter fans haven't really been clamoring for a movie.
movie_title: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The true gist is a kung fu movie for the modern age: jam packed full of the hyper kinetic stimuli of an ADHD generation.
It is a good movie that misses out on greatness simply because it was never really destined for it.

Vampires and romance are nothing new, but Twilight gives them enough of a twist to make it interesting and the film delivers enough on that twist to make it far better than its outlying plot makes it sound.

The Spirit tries hard enough that watching the movie isn't a total bust, but it is that immense effort to try to be something -- anything -- that turns the film into a confused little piece of visual nothingness.
The Wrestler contains what is hands down the best performance of the year.
Gran Torino is Clint Eastwood doing what Clint Eastwood does best.
Is Benjamin Button the best film of the year? I'm not sure, but it is definitely good enough to be.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Wow.

Even once the "scary" monsters start ramping up their appearances the film is still dead and Goyer's direction feels more like a trippy music video for some Eastern European techno band than anything out of a horror film.
Paul Blart delivers laughs, yes, but it's only one great slapstick actor and a little bit of heart away from being just another truly idiotic comedy.
My Bloody Valentine is full of everything that makes B-Grade horror great: blood, blood and blood.
Would it be a valid review if there was just a picture of a cookie cutter on this page instead of text?
The film's premise is obviously a little shaky, but if you're looking for straight out, cold, hard action than there is nothing better for you than Taken.
If you really want to see this movie just go home and rent Friday the 13th parts 1-3 and if you want to see the best film in the series rent part 6.

It's even more disappointing because from the general plot of the film it is clear that had the film makers gone in a few different directions Shopaholic could have been a colorful dress from Betsey Johnson instead of just another little black noth
Check my man card at the door and begin making fun of me because I have to admit to completely enjoying Fired Up!.
Bride Wars is absolutely harmless in the worst kind of way.
Legend is definitely a visually striking film, but next time (if there is a next time) I'll want a bit more behind the pretty pictures.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The amount of truth in The Ugly Truth is null and void, and that means you're just left with The Ugly.

Director Neil Blomkamp, whose future in Hollywood should now be a lock, along with screenwriter Terri Tatchell (not to mention Peter Jackson, the film's producer) have created a world with massive scope.
What can I say, I'm just a sucker for a large, muscular man dressed in a tutu.
What you get with When in Rome is a surprisingly good romantic comedy.
The kind of action movie that makes you wish there was a partially rotten tomato.
Of course a flat Scorsese film is still deeper and more textured than almost everything else out there, so this still ranks up there among the must sees.
It's easy to see why one should shove The Crazies aside as another dumb slasher, but it's harder to actually do that.
To summarize this angry rant: boring, cliché, too serious and a waste of an icon.
As superhero movies go this one is definitely a winner.
This is one book worth watching.

It's not just good punch lines, and it's not just parody, and it's not just a man sticking a stalk of celery up his ass to distract some guards. MacGruber is all these things, and it's damn funny because of it.
You might have to be hankering for a dumb action flick to really get your money's worth in the theater, but if you are that is exactly what you will get.
Do not fret, unwilling patrons dragged along to a viewing, the movie is actually quite entertaining in its own right.
Despicable Me plays it right down the line, and delivers on that line in a perfect fashion.
Turtletaub has already proven he can avoid logic spectacularly well in the National Treasure films and he does it again here as well. It isn't a bad thing.

Nolan's greatest aspect might be his own ability to show restraint when he could easily over blow everything. It worked miracles in Dark Knight and it has crafted a masterpiece in the form of Inception.

It's hard to call this a bad movie as it is wonderfully and beautifully shot and directed, but its failure to grasp any meaning in its end and its steady decent into boredom make it a failure as a movie overall.
Easily the plot of a vulgar comedy or something with absolutely no meaning, The Extra Man is dark, funny and thoughtful all at once.
The Karate Kid just won the award for surprise of the year. It's good.
I don't think I've seen an untested film franchise be set up for a sequel so hard in my entire life.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Cookie-cutter rom-coms can work well, but this is one you can skip any year.
In the end the great performances can't save the film. Mediocrity drips from every other aspect of the film, and you can feel it trying too hard to convince us that we should care.

Post Grad heaps more bad on top of the bad that it has already delivered until all it can do is wallow in its own cliche, wondering why even the teenage girls in the front row of the theater -- the very girls that should be lapping its message up -
Taking Woodstock is a fine film, it just isn't what it wants to be or what it should be.
It isn't simply interesting to see how American Vogue is put together, but actually fun, humorous and insightful. Plus, Wintour is really a b**ch sometimes, and that is always good to watch.
Extract actually has to extract its laughs from the movie (pardon the pun), and that is something great comedy never has to do.
In an ultimate twist of irony for those who have seen the movie, the film lacks soul.
Jennifer's Body is horror thrown back at us with it's tongue firmly in its cheek and its conventions open for all to see.
Surrogates is yet another film that got swallowed by the Hollywood machine and spit out the other side. It's a surrogate of itself.
Invictus is not a bad movie. It's quite a good movie, in fact. It is simply not a great movie, and, unfortunately for it, expectations were high.
For fans of the genre I can't see Pandorum disappointing.
Whip It is good, it just needs to be whipped into better shape.
For those of us who were weened on the idea that we're all "money, and we don't even know it" Couples Retreat is a little difficult to see, but is it bad? Not entirely. It's not entirely good either.
This isn't a horror film, it's a a lesson in how to build fear.
If you've ever wanted to see what 3D could actually do for a film if it wasn't just used as a gimmick then check out A Christmas Carol.
If the world had actually ended two hours into the film we'd all be discussing how awesomely stupid 2012 was in heaven.

All I can really say is that if liking a movie where two guys swing off of ropes tied to a building into a window with guns blazing and proceed to slide across the floor on their knees while shredding mobsters up with bullets is wrong, then I don't want t
movie_title: The Boondock Saints II: All Saints Day (2009)

movie_review_blurb: One can't really complain about delivering what the fans want, can one?
Zombieland is a bloody, gorey, funny, over-the-top, zombie slaughtering piece of perfection.
They adapted the story for the medium instead of the medium for the story, and it's a beautiful thing to see.
If you want good revenge read some Shakespeare, if you want blood see a slasher, if you want to waste two hours then visit the last house on the left.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: You leave feeling like they took the images of these characters of childhood wonder and emptied them out of all their wonder.
Furious 7 is everything you expect it to be. An over-the-top car chase film jam packed with fist fights, gun battles, insanely awesome set pieces and lots of dialog about family.
It's one you're going to want to see because when it shines, it shines bright, but Avengers: Age of Ultron is just a little worrying that the universe is already buckling under its own weight.

In a world of action cinema that is becoming more cookie cutter and glossy via every superhero sequel and young adult adaptation Mad Max: Fury Road is a breath of old air. The kind of R-rated action that's gritty, dirty and non-stop.
Great films have meaning to their message, all Tomorrowland does is shout from the mountain top that we're doing it all wrong. Well, Brad Bird, so are you.

San Andreas just wants to show destruction and it wants you to revel in it. That's nearly impossible given the timing of the release and the fact that reveling in nothing but glorified destruction got old at least five years ago.
There's nothing wrong with a film for the fans, unless you're not one.
So there are some words on Inside Out. They're OK. I still don't think I got it right. I guess the only words I really need to write are: see this movie.
Dear Diary, Channing Tatum is soooo cute. I wish he'd play a werewolf and fight vampires and wear eyeliner and no shirt.

If you want abs, strippers, thrusting loins and more dollar bills than you've ever seen before in a movie then Magic Mike XXL delivers. It's just too bad it couldn't deliver the entire package (pun totally intended).
Let's just say it's fine to see once, but not worth hanging around. That's some gallows humor, right there.
It's exactly what the MCU needs right now: a creative dose of fun.
Southpaw doesn't give you that thrill and because of that it can throw a few good punches, but it never lands a KO.
Vacation is a movie that no one wanted so it's hard to say that it's a major disappointment.
Henry Cavill is a really, really, really attractive human being.

I made the horrible mistake of watching Mad Max: Fury Road the night before this. It was like hearing the London Symphony Orchestra perform and then listening to a five-year-old smash his hands into a Casio keyboard.
While it might not be anything that's going to change how you see survival movies it will reconfirm one thing: climbing a mountain is not something you want to do.

It's an interesting commentary on itself that many seem to have missed, dismissing the movie as overly complex, but it smartly tells you exactly how to enjoy this film: keep moving and don't look back.
There has never been and may never be a better advertisement for NASA or a better explanation of why it's so important for us to explore.

Do not pay for this movie, do not rent this movie, but if, late one night, you find yourself flipping through channels and you see Jennifer Lopez in her underwear getting it on with a walking, talking six-pack stick around and have some fun.
American Sniper hits on the sniper part of its title, but sadly forgets to talk about the American.
Dawn is proof that with the right director and some care a remake or sequel can go further than anything that has come before it. Evidently there's still some creativity left in big budget Hollywood.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: When the movie finally does decide to deliver the turtles we came to see it does it well. I just wish they remembered who the movie was named after sooner.

What makes this truly appalling is that every so often the film actually tries to connect its ludicrous and action oriented storm scenes with the tragic destruction that has recently torn through the Midwest.
Finally an 'Expendables' that isn't so expendable
The film just falls flat, which is ironic since the 3D looks stunning.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: When the Game Stands Tall is a mess of a film that gets lost in its inability to tell a single story.
It helps to have Denzel Washington delivering your one-liners and threats, but the real charm of The Equalizer is not that it is better than it should be, but that it is exactly how it should be.
Like a bad thriller trying to be a Michael Mann film
Annabelle knows how to play with its toys.
More Baymax, please
Mockingjay succeeds where the book failed
In this day and age we get big and brash every other week from our movies so you better have something else to back it up.

The movie is a visual triumph as all of the films have been, but pretty pictures only get you so far, and with five other films full of pretty Middle Earth pictures they garner even less distance here.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The movie itself is harmless and needless and would have been forgotten by the ages if it weren't for the fact that it gave us one last chance to remember something greater.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: What matters is that a film about a protest in 1965 is powerfully relevant to today and should be required viewing for the year.
A paint by numbers retelling of a fantastic story that pulls at the heartstrings with cliche rather than true emotion.

The most brilliant editing of the year revs you up as it interlaces the apex of story lines, and then explodes into a giant orgasm of emotional and physical movie making only to roll over, light a cigarette and stop paying attention to you.
We're forced to watch uncomfortably as McCarthy seemingly shills herself out as the big, funny girl.
Crimson Peak is a visually stunning mess.
If you didn't see Spectre, in all it's incredibly traditional Bond glory, coming you weren't paying attention. The questions is are the old ways really better?
I won't always love you.

Look, I'm all for action movies where an American flies to some country and starts shooting, but if you're going to involve the CIA, very real-world terrorists, torture, the Iranian government, and an atomic bomb, then you can't make that movie anymore.
The Golden Circle pushes the ridiculousness even further, and while it doesn't make for a bad movie at all, it makes for one that has less staying power and feeling.
Liman appears to be the only director working these days that can pull old Tom Cruise out of his malaise and make him deliver the performances we know Tom Cruise can deliver.
Mancini writes and directs the movie like everyone cares deeply about these people coming back when all we may kind of be interested in is Chucky going on a killing spree.
Blade Runner 2049 is a fantastic movie with bold ideas, visually stunning direction, and powerful performances. But underneath it all lies a Hollywood reboot.
While it may lose some of its punch in its drive for comedic set ups, it still finds its heart at the end.
The solution to tackling a big, messy, interesting, unique world? Condense it down to nothing.
Well they did it, folks. DC made two movies in a row that don't suck. So... good for them. Well done.
Scott actually did it. In under a month, he replaced an actor using almost no digital fakery. It's quite the feat. It's just unfortunate the film doesn't really deserve that much effort.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As good as it should be
The most January movie to ever January.
Have you ever wanted to watch General Hux at his most detached strangle the life out of realistic looking bunny while he curses him for driving him to murder?
Not since Ant-Man has a Marvel film actually been about the hero in the title, but Black Panther is and it makes it all the better.
The cultural references crammed in everywhere should have given the movie heart, but instead they feel like contractual obligations.
Bond. James Bond is back.

The Last Jedi opens up with one of the best space fights the series has seen, and it carries that quality throughout. It has one of the best light saber fights, one of the best endings, and some of the most fun the series has seen.
When a Saturday morning cartoon involving a woman literally projecting a different person on top of herself handles this metaphor better than you do then you've got serious problems.
Baby Driver should be seen simply because it is such a bold and wonderful idea. That's why I kind of hate to say that it doesn't pull it off fully.
Universal wants to establish a "dark" universe, but there's nothing dark about this movie at all except for its insistence to mute every color in existence.
The 33 does not try hard. It performs its tale to perfectly perfunctory satisfaction.

This is the beginning of something. It's a farewell to the old guard and a welcome to the new. As such it's hard to begrudge the film its plethora of callbacks, repeated plot line and heavy exposition.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: I think timing and mediocrity will turn Sisters into a forgotten footnote of cinematic history.
Ignoring the politics of the subject matter might be both the worst and best thing the movie does, simultaneously making it work and fail at the exact same time.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's cheap and lackluster, and it's hard to imagine what another entire film is even going to be about or why anyone would want to see it after sitting through this one.
'BvS' is a short cut so concerned with setting up the next films to come it forgets that it needs to work as one itself.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Those visuals, though. You will spend half this movie wondering what is real and what isn't while marveling at the individual hairs on Baloo's back or how Baheera moves perfectly or how the fat on King Louie is disturbingly realistic.
Giving this movie money is re-enforcing everything wrong with the industry, and possibly everything wrong with the world.
The film equivalent of the KKK projectile vomiting onto celluloid while a group of men attempt to write a screenplay about women with their privates.
By this time one would think that the Marvel formula was getting old and that it wouldn't work anymore, and yet the studio just keeps making it better.
The Nice Guys is a strange combination of what Sean Black does best, but his neo-noir feels awkward mixed with buddy cop.

Thankfully for the world (and to the detriment of Internet rage) it turns out that women can be funny, Paul Feig is still a great comedy director and Ghostbusters is a highly entertaining movie that both goes its own way and pays homage.
Sully is another testament to just how deft a filmmaker Eastwood is because it's easy to tell the "true" story of a hero, but it's hard to tell the true story of a man.
We've been over saturated with the genre and so to really stand out it needed to do something new, and it just doesn't.
While Kong: Skull Island can get drastically stupid at times it always seems aware of this and it has figured out an antidote: Kong smash.
The first movie was such a surprise and so damn charming, that it's impossible for Vol. 2/i> to regain that feeling, but it makes its own, and it owns it. Even if it didn't it has baby Groot.
What made for great dialog in a videogame in 2002 makes for cliche in the midst of an animation renaissance in 2016.
There's plenty of good to watch here, but this time around Carney's soul seems to be missing.

Even more disastrous is the film's treatment of women who are seen almost entirely as either sex objects or foils for men to play off of. A woman's only use in this film is to advance the plot by making mistakes.
Sometimes it's good to be wrong... twice.
"Hey, look who's here," the film says excitedly as Rudd and Fey routinely attempt to make a stale screenplay humorous, "Why aren't you laughing at them?"
Now you know G.I. Joe: Retaliation is a fun movie, and knowing is half the battle.

Bloody, disgusting, dark, scary and all with just a very small hint of that classic Raimi slapstick, the new Evil Dead delivers what you'd expect in spades and then goes beyond to both gross you out and kick some butt.
A wonderfully gorgeous and nostalgic film whose story doesn't live up to its look.
While it may not be the best baseball film ever, the movie leading up to that cliched home run crack of the bat is definitely worth watching.
For most directors this film would be high octane, but for Bay it's practically a three hour art house film showing a flower blooming in excruciatingly slow motion.
That is why Iron Man 3 does a very smart thing, something comic fans have always known is what makes comics great: it takes a superhero and focuses on the man.
New drinking game: take a shot every time the American Flag or a Presidential portrait shows up in Olympus Has Fallen.

What I want to believe is that Luhrmann was striving for his own green light at the end of the pier, and the only way he knew how to even try to reach it was to go all out. If he succeeded is up to you, but I'm a believer in his truly orgastic attempt.

The film is somehow both over-plotted and yet completely lacking in story and the action just too disjointed to work. I still want a sequel, and that's because Optimus Prime riding on a Dinobot is really freaking awesome.
You may come away from it with your heart warmed and your feel-good comedy spot hit, but you won't come away from it remembering anything.
By focusing on the super and not the man Man of Steel doesn't deliver Superman.
Holy crap, it doesn't suck.
The film simply is what it is, and that is boring.
It should have been something special, and all we got was more of the norm.
It's almost funny that Sandler's films about being older are his most immature, as if in an attempt to make a movie about recapturing youth, he's showing us exactly why you shouldn't.
What's impressive is that it tops its predecessor, a film that already did big, ridiculous action perfectly.
Cut to black. No. Really. There's a 3 second cut to black that can be interpreted as nothing else than a warning to not go on from here.
This isn't perfect, but it's a crazy interesting movie to watch.
Not sure how it made it off the Hallmark Channel to the big screen.
A few hitches, but they don't cock it up too much.
It may not be the story the book told in content and tone, but it's the story it had to be... plus 30 minutes.

If the goal of Apatow was to make a film that in itself was a metaphor for a 40-year-old person having a failed mid-life crises than he succeeded, if it was to actually make a good movie about being 40 than he failed.
A movie that's only true achievement is that it remains palatable instead of veering off into the "KILL IT BEFORE IT DESTROYS ALL OF FUNNY THINGS!" zone.
While nothing will be as powerful as seeing it live on stage, Hooper directs the film with a straight forward brashness that shows a brave faith in his actors and the material.

The story of the hunt for Osama Bin Laden starts long before he was shot in his outpost in Pakistan, and if you're looking for the tale of Seal Team Six and their heroics that night than this is not your movie.
Where originality goes to get mowed down by a Tommy gun.
Mama turns out to be a film that doesn't go far enough into its own concept, skirting the edges of edginess without ever wanting to actually commit to it.
No, Arnold still can't act all that well, and may have in fact lost a step since his heyday, but the man is given the lines he needs and spits them out like an old pro.
Schreck has crafted a moving tribute to Richard Williams's artistic ambition, and at the same time celebrates the melancholy beauty of impossible dreams.

You want blood (check), fights (check), breasts (check) and Christian Slater acting like a mad man (check). If that is absolutely all you want out of this movie then you are not going to leave displeased.
John McClean goes to Chernobyl. That's where we're at. Chernobyl.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A bit of editing down and a lot less self-importance could have made this not only a compelling drama, but a compelling argument that Johnson could be more than just an action star.
There are definitely worse things than a movie that's just a bit of fun without doing anything special. Of course, there are definitely much better things too.
I was really torn about this movie so I decided to like it because Bruce Campbell is in it.
What's obvious here is that Joss Whedon is a great director, Shakespeare is a great writer and if you get a cast together that really clicks you're going to make a fun movie.
It's an impressively simple film that hits all the right notes between drama and humor.
I feel the need... the need for speed(y snails)
This isn't an instant classic, but it definitely reaffirms that Wan can do some interesting things within the horror genre.
After Earth is not as bad as The Last Airbender. Yes, you heard it here first: After Earth is not as bad as one of the worst big budget films ever released. So, better than bad? It still ain't good.
Kick-Ass 2 contains almost all the same themes and ideas as the original, but it wears them on its sleeve and in its openness loses the very themes it is so obviously trying to express.

The Monuments Men is the kind of film you flip over to accidentally when searching through channels and finally watch it. Then is a perfect time to sit through it, but it doesn't warrant anymore viewing effort than happenstance allows.

Round the kids up (or don't), plop yourself down in a theater (no need to pay extra for 3D) and get ready to remember how great it was to open a box of random LEGO parts and find the world was just full of blocky possibilities of where to go next.
Despite its tonal issues, RoboCop is a blast to see and a fantastic return to a new form for a character that always deserved more love.
The thinking seems to be that when you already know that everyone is going to die at the end it makes it kind of hard to make any plot interesting so why not try them all out and see if any stick.
3 Days to Kill is a bit confused about what it wants to be, but some of the things its trying on work and that makes it worth killing some time with -- just not at full price at a movie theater.
This is the Veronica Mars fans have been dying for, and if that means non-fans aren't going to have as good a time as fans at the movie then screw them, they should be fans in the first place.
It's easy to point out the faults in We're the Millers because it is definitely not a complete comedy, but it is the funniest one this summer.
That Awkward Moment feels awkward itself as it shouts out desperately for us to tell it how clever and funny it is.
While the move does have some visually striking moments, and a fantastic mob kill to push it into slasher territory it can't put its interesting pieces together into something that thrills or scares.
Somewhere between Arnold's recent fare of dumb action and Ayers's history of dark, smart cop dramas we find Sabotage

It's a despicable film that clearly has no idea what it's doing as it contradicts its own themes, eventually landing in a big puddle of false feminism that would set the movement back years if anyone actually cared about the movie.
Godzilla might miss out on the perfect film it could be, but it's definitely the film it should be.
A charming cast makes it succeed, but a lack of willingness to really push boundaries never lets it become anything more.
It does not make you want to gouge your eyes out in horror. It is not the anti-Christ. This is not a worse movie than Grown Ups 2. Not exactly praise, but it should take what it can get.
For a man who mocks pop culture so well he can barely pull of the most American of pop culture, the western.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It works in both action and humor and deftly handles what could have been an overly complicated story.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Noah works when its about Noah.
Don't even get in the car.
From the moment a train pulled into a station filmmakers have been trying to present life to us -- to tell us its story -- and Linklater may have now come the closest.
I am now staking my claim that despite the fact that I have seen no other 2014 movies, none of them will be worse than this.
Chris Pine as Jack Ryan in a true spy thriller could do marvels if the first half of this movie is any indication. Too bad there's a second half.
This is one of the most creative, original, genre exploring blood baths in a good long while.
The entire experience has a pulp feel to it, like they're channeling old science fiction serials.
Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 is a sequel that wasn't needed and feels like it.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: This is a movie for movie theaters. This is a film that cannot be appreciated to its full extent off of the big screen. Gravity is why movie theaters exist.
Paying for this movie won't make you angry, but it will give you a chance to catch a solid nap in a nice cool theater.
The decision to put a trailer for Machete Kills Again... in Space! at the beginning of the film might have been a mistake since that looks better than this one.
Carrie does just enough new to excuse iTs existence as a remake, but it never truly gets its own ball rolling.
It's just too bad that no one reeled in Daniels' direction as he too often lets the film turn into a sermon instead of a lesson.

By grounding the film in a haunted house-style horror movie and making Chucky a creepy doll again, while still maintaining the warped humor that the first three films had, it may deliver the best film in the franchise.
I'm all for movies that don't hold your hand, but ambiguity should not be mistaken for intelligence.
Your worst fears might be true; Ender's Game has really been turned into an action movie, but it does just enough to still reflect the social and emotional issues that the book tackles.

It almost ignores its central time travel concept and instead focuses on an unbridled joy in love. Can that get too sweet and sugary? Of course, but sometimes a dose of sweet and sugary is perfectly welcome.
At the end of the film, Death comments that he sees humanity's beauty and ugliness and always wonders how the same thing can be both. Well, The Book Thief isn't both. It's just ugly.
If you're a fan of Jackson's prolific Middle Earth than you're going to be a fan of this movie. If you came to see the original story of The Hobbit unfold then you'll like about 20 minutes.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Grudge Match is definitely not your best option in theaters this holiday. Far, far, far, far... far... really, really, really far from it. That being said, and despite the fact that it is cliche and obvious, the movie delivers some heart.

I really want to see the movie that Cumberbatch thought he was in because his performance has so many interesting aspects it couldn't possibly be for what amounts to a nearly paint by numbers thriller.
The problem is Elektra is not among the most compelling of characters. She doesn't have enough humanity and the story not enough depth to sustain us between fight scenes.

The Last Men in Aleppo documents a catastrophic crisis that still requires international attention, its mishmash of methods produce an effective end result, albeit lacking considerable evocation beyond the subject's raw intensity to sway its audience.

While Schröder has proven on multiple occasions to be a powerful documentarian capturing uniquely engaging instances and peoples, Big Time doesn't even come close to being on par with that of his previous works, and is borderline forgettable as a result.

Though its composition of the subject matter is not too uncommon, the docu remains unique due to the expansive knowledge and perspectives utilized to prove its central themes...Oklahoma City is far more a commentary than historical document.
The Young Karl Marx fumbles too often to be emotional compelling or intellectually stimulating.
movie_title: The Young Karl Marx (Le jeune Karl Marx) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Ultimately, Manolo: The Boy Who Made Shoes For Lizards is better at capturing the tones of the times visited rather than proving the significance of its subject.
movie_title: Manolo, The Boy Who Made Shoes For Lizards (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It aims to be a good family film for the summer movie season, and it fits right in with the buttery popcorn I ate while watching it.
Who would have thought one of the deepest films ever made about learning disabilities would star a talking blue fish?
It is one of the best movies to ever come out of the Marvel Cinematic Universe, balancing engaging action set pieces and witty dialogue with intelligent character studies and ethical debates.
Based on the screening I attended, I can attest that audiences seemed to genuinely enjoy the jokes and get swept up in the action sequences.
It is without question an important film today, and a quintessential product of the America we inhabit.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: With "1776," political struggles that took place nearly two-and-a-half centuries ago feel as fresh and immediate as the political struggles of today.
When it comes to its underlying racial message, "The Ridiculous Six" still grates, and there are obvious moments when it appears to be punching down almost without realizing it.

"Split" takes a step in this direction by positing that "mental sickness" might not always be an actual illness - but then takes two steps back by exploiting moviegoers' fears that people with unusual mental conditions can be unpredictably violent.
Despite all the substandard characterization, what we do see sucks us in enough to keep us invested and, at times, riveted.
Aspie Seeks Love is as much a critique of American dating culture as it is a portrait of high-functioning autism.
It feels less like a movie than a series of compromises worked out by a corporate committee.
It's fair to say that "Pirates of Silicon Valley" established the standard that all worthy movies about the computer revolution will need to follow.
It strikes the balance between referencing its nostalgic origins without being obnoxious or obsequious in doing so.
Would I still recommend "An Inconvenient Sequel"? Sure, although I doubt there is much one could glean from this movie that couldn't be obtained by rewatching "An Inconvenient Truth."
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In that limited sense, "Death Wish" is a success, albeit one that action fans should wait to see on Netflix.
If "Spider-Man: Homecoming" is to be judged solely on its ability to unite a diverse audience behind a fun motion picture, it seems to have succeeded wildly.
This isn't the story of Barnum's life, but a formulaic rags-to-riches story grafted onto the broad outlines of Barnum's career as a circus entrepreneur.

He no doubt intended to make a provocative film that would inspire its viewers to become activists for socioeconomic justice. Instead, this is a movie that conservatives should embrace as a huge favor to their cause.
Audiences seem to be smart enough these days to know a good movie when they see it, and to avoid a bad flick despite Hollywood's best efforts to pull a fast one on them.
When it comes to creative visuals, engaging action and likable characters, "Black Panther" stands confidently next to the best fare offered up by the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
The characters aren't as obnoxious and unlikable as the ones in "Smiley" and "Unfriended," but then again, bland and forgettable is only a marginally preferable alternative.

I'm writing this not so much as a critic but as an ordinary moviegoer, experiencing Proustian transport via an old-fashioned scary movie executed by a team of filmmakers and actors at the top of their game.
Beneath the melodrama of the maneuvering for power, there are millions of ordinary human beings who depend on the right outcome.
"Brigsby Bear" is a funny, oddly touching look at the pros and cons of millennials' tendency to obsess over pop culture.

I'm sure some will disagree with the points that Davis Guggenheim is making. That's to be expected but it will help generate a badly needed debate on this subject matter.
Aaron Eckhart is great in a comedy (Thank You For Smoking) and great in a drama (Rabbit Hole) but he's not the sort of guy you want leading a sci-fi action film.
I'm describing it as being like the pilot for a cheesy 90s sitcom that no television network wanted to buy.
The filmmakers have gone with a stock-standard mould that offers nothing new. If there was a surprise... it was just how boring these characters were.
I'm not convinced that there's a clear message but this is still a film worth your attention. The editing is sharp and the cinematography is striking.
The characters extricate themselves far too easily from difficult situations and there's no sense of excitement.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There's nothing really special about this latest instalment in the Narnia franchise but it finishes strongly and is worth a look.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: From its wide panoramic vistas to its tight close ups, Hughes has created a suspenseful setting.
The well choreographed action scenes mask the many weaknesses within the story.
[The] glimpse of the real Blair was far more interesting than the clichéd version we saw throughout the film.
It sounds bad but I still had fun. It's got creative dance moves, decent choreography and a solid soundtrack.
We're all entitled to our own opinions regarding his past but Polanski deserves credit as a filmmaker. The Ghost Writer proves that he's as good as ever at the age of 77.
About half way through this film, I realised I had let my guard down. I was having too much fun. My critic's hat had fallen off.
It's trying to be funny and it's trying to be cool but Killers doesn't quite get there.
Meredith has a bath. Meredith milks a cow. Meredith chases a sheep. These scenes left me shaking my head with disbelief. Who could possibly find this interesting?
Inception may be the most intelligent action film you will ever see.
Some viewers will be turned off by this non-Stiller role but I think he's great. He also gets a few quotable lines thanks to writer-director Noah Baumbach.
This isn't the best Aussie film of the year but with strong performances and a distinct setting, it warrants your attention.
Knight And Day runs out of ammunition (unlike its characters) well before the closing credits start to roll.
Featuring a mix of English, French and Russian, Farewell is a solid thriller.
It's not as good as the first film but it's better than the second film. Make of that as you will.
A fun adventure with plenty of laughs and a strong narrative. It will undoubtedly capture the attention of both kids and adults. It's almost impossible not to like.
Some will love it, some will hate it and the rest will fall somewhere in between.
If you've enjoyed the ride so far, be sure not to miss one last adventure with Shrek and his crew.
Muppets Most Wanted isn't the pinnacle for these beloved characters... but it should keep children entertained.
It starts out as a fairly innocuous comedy but it gradually develops into something more dramatic, more meaningful.
My criticisms regarding the story's delivery are largely negated by the strong performances from Sean Penn and Naomi Watts.
Mia Hansen-Løve deserves credit both as a writer and a director. This is a very convincing drama.
movie_title: The Father of My Children (Le pere de mes enfants) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The dialogue is cheesy but I was impressed by the tension that builds throughout the film.
It's the kind of movie that pulls you into its setting and doesn't let go.
It's shocking, it's hilarious but most importantly, it's eye-opening.
Bill Nighy nabs most of the laughs with his suave, sarcastic, sophisticated character.
It deserves credit for its style but the holes in the screenplay were too hard for me to ignore.
What I enjoyed about this film was the many different angles from which the story is explored.
There are a few "jump out of your seat" moments but when you break it down, it's just a simple rehash of the original.
I've never harnessed a desire to visit Mildura but that's changed thanks to the beautiful cinematography of Greg De Marigny.
How many more Resident Evil films are they going to make? Hopefully the answer is zero.
You’ll be watching in awe as Fincher weaves the scenes of this film together. There’s never a dull moment.
There’s too much eating, too much praying and too much loving. I should have known given the title.
Whether you like it or not, Buried is a film that will stick in your memory.
I had a lot more fun earlier in the year watching talking toys and fire-breathing dragons.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard to feel sorry for someone who seems to instigate so many of his own problems.
Whilst it's not as memorable as the original, I've always got time for a well-written thriller.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This could have been a gritty, realistic drama but the writers have gone with a safer, more commercial option. The unsatisfying ending is proof of that.
I wasn't sure what to expect from the unorthodox pairing of Will Ferrell and Mark Wahlberg but it turns out they make a likeable comedic duo.
If you like a good twist, then this is the next film you must see. Your eyes will be glued to the screen, wondering what unexpected plot developments lay ahead.
I didn't take a lot away from the film but there are some wonderfully uncomfortable scenes that make it worth seeing.
I personally wouldn't consider it a game-changer but The Cabin In The Woods kept me on my toes and has many interesting elements.
Sticking with the same winning formula, Phillips has made a near carbon copy of the original. This makes it less surprising but still entertaining.
I can live with his approach but it feels like Vaughn was afraid to pull the curtain back and truly expose the mutants' fragile state. He's kept things simpler, easier to handle.
I found this to be a peculiar movie. Some parts drew me in whilst other, not-so-believable parts, pushed me away.
It meanders along with poor developed characters and culminates with a weak finale that tries too hard to please.
The subject matter is interesting but I was disappointed with its delivery. The screenplay is repetitious.
I didn't want either of the two guys to earn her affections. They're both superficial jerks - an opinion that didn't change throughout the entire film.
It's an insane, relatively predictable storyline and you'd think they'd be able to weave more humour into the mix.
The story is fascinating in itself but it's Steve McQueen's careful direction that gives it a seductive, hypnotic edge.
Looking deep into the psyche of this troubled individual, Durkin isn't offering any easy answers... and nor should he be.
You're likely to be as smiling as much as George Valentin.
I can't recall too many wedding flicks that have been this crazy and this outlandish. I certainly had a lot of fun watching it!
Through two wonderful performances from Tom Cullen and Chris New, writer-director Andrew Haigh has captured the many emotions associated with a new relationship.
Mavis Gary is an absorbing individual and credit goes to Academy Award winning writer Diablo Cody for creating her.
If you enjoy an intelligent, realistic spy thriller, Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy is not to be missed.
This is still a slick, gripping thriller and Fincher's stylish fingerprints can be seen all the way through.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Speaking insightfully and realistically, George Clooney, Shailene Woodley and Amara Miller are a delight to watch.
These characters have become too smart for their own good. The never-ending banter between Robert Downey Jr and Jude Law gets tired quickly.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The limitations within the screenplay are largely offset by Janusz Kaminski's beautiful cinematography, Michael Kahn's nicely-paced editing and John Williams's sweet film score.
I don't want to give too much away but this unsettling tale is told so beautifully, so precisely.
An outsider could see these characters as misguided. That's not the reality however. Farhadi slips us into their shoes and we appreciate each of their perspectives.
Fabrice Luchini (Potiche) is immensely likeable as the film's shy leading man and the chatty maids have a humorous, cheeky disposition.
movie_title: Les femmes du 6e étage (The Women on the 6th Floor) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Each character seems to be rushing through their arguments and it's as if every single word has been over thought.
With a script void of shouting matches and preachy monologues, J.C. Chandor makes the brave decision not to demonise these characters.
Getting the best of the laughs is the underrated Adam Scott who as Jason, is never afraid to share what's on his mind.
The lead role didn't necessarily require someone younger but it needed an actor with more flair and charisma.
These women have nothing that interesting to offer and their husbands are just as dull.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It's an interesting premise but sadly, Bel Ami is a film that underachieves. I found it a continual struggle to understand the mindset of each character.
While acknowledging that some of the film's individual scenes are quite funny, the overarching story needed work.
There were only a handful of genuine laughs... and that puts it on a par with Scary Movie 3.
It's one of the best superhero movies ever and excels in terms of three key genres - action, comedy and suspense.
More time needed to be spent exploring these characters as opposed to showing us picturesque landscapes to the backdrop of songs preaching about love and sunshine.
Whilst I hoped there would be a little more substance, I still found myself caught up in the charm of this farce.
There's nothing original in the script from brothers Jon and Erich Hoeber and they've failed to create any interesting characters despite a running time of more than two hours.
I had no issues with the charming Emily Blunt but I found Ewan McGregor's character too nerdish and boring.
It was nice to catch up with these people but I grew tired in the later stages and remembered why we haven't stayed in touch.
There are only a few laughs and the characters aren't that exciting. I much preferred Kung Fu Panda will all its action and fighting.
Wrath Of The Titans is at its most entertaining when the characters give up on the dull dialogue and simply let the action do the talking.
From the décor in the luxurious apartments to the little curls at the end of Wes Bentley's beard, this is a film with a strong visual footprint.
Despite the strong performances, the film does feel stuffy with its forced, predictable storyline.
For the most part, it's just plodding along with the occasional dash of humour.
It may be 400 years since Shakespeare penned this work but the story feels just as relevant today with its exploration of war and politics.
Oceans contains some of the most beautiful imagery ever seen in a feature-length documentary.
The script won't take home any awards but you won't care once you've seen the unrelenting action sequences. My eyes were glued to the screen and my heart rate definitely increased!
I'd strongly urge you to hand over a $10 donation and support The Ides Of March. It has my endorsement!
Before finalising any "best of" list for 2011, I'd strongly suggest you see this film.
I realise that action movies aren't meant to be realistic but these characters needed to be far more interesting and believable if they were going to draw me in.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It was this second half of the film I enjoyed most. The cheesy dialogue is left behind and we get to see these characters (including Red Dog himself) at their most vulnerable.
The first half hour feels too much like a history lesson but from thereon in, The Conspirator is a compelling drama.
Hanna is an intriguing action-thriller that's best described as a cross between Run Lola Run and The Bourne Identity.
It felt like I was being smothered with "feel good" moments. Everything about the story and its characters is too far detached from reality.
It's pretty hard to enjoy a romantic comedy when there isn't a single likeable character.
It's not the best in the series but it's a worthy enough conclusion. I had the same thoughts when I read the final book a few years ago.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: I'm describing I Love You Phillip Morris as an inferior version of Catch Me If You Can. It's trying to tell a similar story in a similar vein but it just doesn't work.

There are some touching scenes between father and son but the rest of the film felt too heavy-handed.
It focuses too heavily on flashy action sequences and lacks the amusing banter that I remember fondly from the original.
Sleeping Beauty is a tiring, emotionless experience. I can best describe it as a film that is "all style and no substance".
Some of the film's themes are a touch overdone but I'd strongly recommend this for lovers of great French cinema.
I'm sure many will see it for its gross-out moments but I was more impressed with how the film captures the fragility of its imperfect characters.
Director Jim Loach has done a beautiful job capturing the heart and soul of these characters.
It's so much fun to watch these cheeky, loveable kids pull together and navigate their way through this extraordinary adventure.
The story is a little too compact at times but the exquisite performance of Mia Wasikowska makes this film stand out.
One of the funniest films I've seen all year. It's faithful to the TV series and I can too easily relate to these four guys and their hilarious insecurities.
Is there anyone who can play an "ordinary guy" better than Paul Giamatti?
Brendan Gleeson's performance in The Guard will be remembered as one of the best of 2011.
I'm not sure why Santa is portrayed as such as a schmuck early on and this is part of the reason why I think kids will be sitting there with a blank stare on their face.
Matthew Goode delivers a wonderful performance as Tom. He's a character that you want to sympathise with but he makes it difficult with some of his not-so-likeable outbursts.
This weekend, millions of people around the globe will be conned into handing over their hard earned cash to see a film with no plot, no action and no climax.
It reeled me in very quickly with its interesting story, a few surprising twists and an unexpected number of laughs.
Perhaps there is an element of truth in this tale but director Roland Emmerich makes it very hard to believe with this muddled story.
It has its moments but, for the most part, I found it to be flat and disappointing.
If you can make it through one viewing, I dare say Drive is a film you're going to want to watch again and again.
Even if you can get past the plot holes (and that's a big IF), you'll still be bored by this standard action-thriller. There's very little to get the heart pumping.
I was shaking my head with disbelief as I watched the riders navigate the sharp corners and avoid rock walls by a matter of inches.
If you don't leave the cinema with a smile on your face, I'll be very, very surprised.

What elevates this above your average thriller is the rational manner in which the characters act.
Real Steel is my kind of action movie. The story is engaging, the characters are fun and the robots are freaking cool.
It's a story that could easily be laughed at but Nettheim has transformed it into a moving, compelling drama.
These characters reflect no people that I've ever met. They're as crazy and stupid as the title suggests.
Whilst they hardly say a word, I felt much sorrow for these two lonely characters and the changing world in which they find themselves.
Whilst the bosses are unnecessarily over-the-top, the film still manages to work as a light-hearted buddy comedy.
You'd think that a movie that covers both the science fiction and western genres would be a lot funnier than this.
The Invisible Woman is a satisfying romantic drama that explores a very complex relationship.
The more you think about it, the less sense it makes.... but that's not to say that you can't have fun watching it.

It feels more like a knowledge building history lesson rather than an exciting, free-flowing adventure.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Cinema has the power to open our eyes to the world's issues and offer a path forward if we're willing to take it. I, Daniel Blake is a great example and should not be missed.
Don't go in thinking you can sit back, relax, and enjoy some action-heavy entertainment. Your mind will be put to work.

This is a damn good film and your feelings about the characters will oscillate throughout.

It must have been a dream project for the sound technicians. There are more explosions than a New Year's Eve fireworks show.

You'll be smiling regardless of your age.

While it's great to catch up with these eclectic characters, the screenplay is slight. The first movie was 30 minutes shorter and yet it feels like it covered twice as much material.

Taraji P. Henson, Octavia Spencer and Janelle Monáe are very, very hard to dislike.

This is a terrific drama that highlights what has changed over the past 60 years and what has remained the same.

The film's most positive quality is the performance turned in by James McAvoy. It's a dream role given he plays so many different characters.
This is a remarkably good movie about one man trying to find love and his place in the world.

movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The aliens are freaky and you can't help but root for the humans as they valiantly try to get the upper hand.
The tone is heavy throughout and while Scarlett Johansson commands a strong presence in the leading role, the same can't be said of the supporting characters.
The film is careful not to judge or praise these characters.

Greengrass uses exciting, elaborate chase sequences to compensate for the weak, not-so-interesting narrative. Two lengthy scenes stand out.
Providing a voice to a group of people seldom seen on the big screen, Embrace of the Serpent is a must-see.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The crew spout a bunch of scientific words and come up with solutions that feel too easy. There's not much in the way of character progression either.
This is a delightful, entertaining comedy filled with wonderful dialogue.

Our Kind of Traitor puts all of its key characters to the test.

movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Watching a computer generated Spider-Man fly across the screen in slow-mo, then fast-mo, then slow-mo... it just doesn't generate a lot of excitement.
12 Strong is a story worth telling but I'd have preferred that it ditched the clichés and replaced it with better dialogue.

I knew nothing of these individuals beforehand and so it serves as an eye-opener and a fitting tribute.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

There's no argument that this is a polished production from director Joe Wright.

movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

Delightful coming of age comedy with a terrific cast, a superb script and a genuinely moving finale - it really is the feel-good movie of the year.
Impressively directed, superbly written and featuring strong performances, this is a compelling, thought-provoking and ultimately moving drama with a timely message.
Mildly amusing, mostly tedious British drama that completely fails to live up to its provocative title.
The effects are impressive but the script, acting and direction are desperately dull.
Time-travel gimmick aside, the title is apt, because it feels like we've seen all of this before. Disappointing.
Tenacious D's big screen outing is extremely patchy but the laughs just about compensate for all the dull, unamusing bits.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Watchable, but overly long and ultimately disappointing romcom, despite spirited performances and the occasional sparkly moment.
Probably the weirdest children's movie of the year -- this is slightly too long but it's beautifully made, superbly acted and a lot of fun.

Catherine Hardwicke (Lords of Dogtown, Thirteen) may seem like an unusual choice for a Biblical epic, but she proves an inspired choice, choosing to focus on the authenticity of the story, primarily through Mary.
Daft but nonetheless enjoyable supernatural thriller, featuring some hilariously bad dialogue, impressive special effects and some genuinely creepy scenes.
Lars von Trier must be mellowing in his old age - this is a delightful farce with a frequently hilarious script strong comic performances.
movie_title: The Boss of it All (Direktøren for det hele) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Though not quite as funny, clever or exciting as it thinks it is, this remains a watchable adventure comedy with good comic performances and the occasional moment of inspiration.
A treat for adults and children alike.
Williams emerges as a genuine talent to watch and it will be interesting to see what he does next.

It's probably fair to warn animal-lovers that there's a fair amount of animal distress in the movie - snakes, in particular, get a pretty rough deal all round and the bulls don't seem too happy either.
Zodiac is a thoroughly engrossing, brilliantly directed and superbly acted thriller that is quite simply one of the best films of the year. Unmissable.
Badly written, shockingly acted and appallingly directed threequel that will please precisely no-one.
movie_title: The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause (2006)

movie_review_blurb: With a terrific central performance by Will Smith, this is a well made, sharply written and ultimately uplifting drama, but it really piles on the misery before you get there.
Powerful, superbly directed and frequently harrowing docu-drama with a strong performance by Ai Qin Lin.
Less 8 Mile, more 8 Mile End, this is an enjoyable, if predictable drama, with a superb performance by Walters.
Ridiculous, but nonetheless enjoyable, this drags a lot for the first half but rallies for the final act with a crowd-pleasing one-two of training montage and fight sequences.
Impressively directed, engaging and frequently moving drama, although it's a shame that there isn't a little more crossover with its companion piece.
The performances ensure that this is never less than watchable but it's not as clever or as funny as it should have been.
Patchy thriller that has the occasional lively moment but is mostly confusing, tedious nonsense.
This fascinating, sensitive documentary is an extraordinary film that is both thought-provoking and deeply moving, although it contains images that some viewers may find upsetting.
Hilarious from start to finish, thanks to a terrific cast, inventive direction and a brilliantly written script.
A shocking embarrassment for all concerned, this is a badly written, badly acted and poorly directed mess from start to finish.
Beautifully directed, charmingly surreal and genuinely romantic, this is the perfect offbeat date movie and easily one of the best films of the year.
Like Catherine Hardwicke's Thirteen, only with money, this is an engaging and frequently tense teen drama with a full-on performance from Anne Hathaway.
Enjoyable, well-acted thriller that's ultimately let down by a disappointing final reel. Impressive sheep-wrangling though.

Adrift has its moments but it's a frustrating film in many ways and doesn't really work as a thriller unless you're a confirmed hydrophobic. If people meeting unfortunate watery ends is your thing then rent Open Water instead.
Never less than watchable, thanks to its superb cast, but kids will enjoy it more than adults will.
This is watchable enough as a grisly revenge thriller but it would have worked better without the Lecter connection.
De Niro's second film features terrific performances and several impressive scenes, but he appears to have forgotten to hire an editor.
Enjoyable romantic comedy with likeable characters, a decent script and some surprisingly catchy tunes.
The talented ensemble cast and Carnahan's slick, colourful direction ensure that Smokin' Aces remains an enjoyable and engaging thriller, though the violence may be a bit too strong for some.
Entertaining, impressively directed musical drama with a show-stopping, Oscar-nominated performance by Jennifer Hudson.
Superbly directed, utterly compelling drama with a strong script and deservedly Oscar-nominated performances from both Dench and Blanchett.
Brightly coloured fantasy adventure with a decent premise, but the animated sections don't really work, despite the efforts of a talented cast.
movie_title: Arthur and the Invisibles (Arthur and the Minimoys) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Watchable, decently made drama with some strong performances, but the script is disappointing given the real-life story behind the film.
Running With Scissors has a great cast and an appropriately chaotic nature, but it never really adds up to anything and fails to hit its emotional targets.
Ambitious, beautifully shot and superbly acted, the all-out surrealness of The Fountain may be too much for some, but the rewards are there if you're prepared to surrender yourself to it.
Slightly too long and not quite as worthy as it thinks it is, this is still an entertaining, well acted thriller that manages to raise some important political issues in between the action sequences.
[The Return] isn't creepy enough to really work properly and there's an over-reliance on sudden soundtrack noises in place of actual scares.
A worthy addition to the bodyswap genre, thanks to a decent script and superb performances from its likeable leads.
Paul Giamatti is perfectly cast as Asterix ... and the film delivers as much Roman-bashing, boar-chasing and pirate-sinking as you could possibly hope for from an Asterix film.
Carice van Houten is terrific in the lead role, radiating wit, energy and sex appeal.
Cliched but nonetheless enjoyable - if you liked the first film, you won't be disappointed by the second one. Unless you're an Arsenal fan.
A lifeless waste of time.
movie_title: The Sex Lives of the Potato Men (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Julie Taymor's love-it-or-hate-it musical is hugely ambitious but it works brilliantly, thanks to strong performances, a fantastic script, terrifically integrated songs and Taymor's inspired direction.
Impressively directed, thoroughly engaging drama with terrific performances and a superb script. This is one of the best films of the year.
Mr Woodcock is never less than watchable, thanks to strong performances and some amusing dialogue, but it's badly let down by a disappointingly weak plot.
Badly plotted, poorly directed action flick - it's no surprise this wasn't shown to critics before its release.
Impressively directed, superbly acted thriller, but it moves too slowly to really engage the audience and ultimately works better as a character study.
Dumb comedy in the Napoleon Dynamite mould with a better-than-average gag rate.
Foster is terrific and Jordan's direction is impressive, but the film doesn't quite succeed, due to the strain of trying to be both angry revenge thriller and emotional, thought-provoking drama.
Quote not available.
movie_title: Paradise Lost: Child Murders at Robin Hood Hills (1996)

movie_review_blurb: Impressively directed, politically relevant and occasionally inspirational, this is an enjoyable, engaging drama with strong performances from its talented cast.
Gory but disappointing.
Danny Boyle's sci-fi thriller is enjoyable, well acted and packed with references throughout although it abandons its fascinating premise for a disappointingly conventional finale.
Enjoyably fluffy romantic comedy with a witty script, an 80s-tastic soundtrack and a superb comic performance from James McAvoy.
Tarantino has a blast with this affectionate nod to '70s exploitation flicks, but the dialogue isn't as good as it should have been.
Enjoyable, sharply written and frequently hilarious, this is Adam Sandler's best comedy since The Wedding Singer.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Engaging, well acted and impressively directed German drama, though the ending is a bit of a disappointment.
Emotionally unengaging, overlong and frequently dull drama, despite the best efforts of its talented cast.
Engaging, impressively directed and ultimately disturbing teen drama with a strong central performance from David Kross.
Impressively directed drama with an Oscar-worthy performance from Angelina Jolie, but the story isn't as tense or as moving as it should have been.
Enjoyable, emotionally engaging Australian drama with superb performances from Blethyn and an up-and-coming young cast.
Disappointing French thriller, thanks to a ridiculous plot, overblown direction and some dodgy acting from Clovis Cornillac.
Watchable, low budget British drama with strong performances from Compston and Mullan.
Impressively directed, frequently silly but nonetheless enjoyable thriller that delivers exactly what the title suggests - 86 minutes of non-stop shoot-'em-up fun.
Entertaining, likeable and surprisingly moving documentary with engaging characters and some astute observations about obsession, friendship and the pursuit of fame.
movie_title: In the Hands of the Gods (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A genuinely hilarious teen comedy with a fantastic script and wonderful comic performances from its three leads.
Smartly directed thriller with a witty script, a great performance from Shia LaBeouf and some hugely enjoyable suspense scenes.
Watchable, nostalgia-tinged drama with strong performances from its four leads, though it's not as emotionally engaging as it should have been.
Engaging, well made Western with exciting action sequences, a thought-provoking script and terrific performances from Bale and Crowe.
Rob Zombie's Halloween reboot isn't bad as remakes go, but the prequel scenes are better than the remake scenes.
Enjoyably offbeat comedy drama with likeable characters and a terrific script, though its relentlessly unconventional nature is ultimately frustrating.
Quote not available.
Beautifully shot, superbly directed biopic with a great script and a terrific performance from newcomer Sam Riley.
Superbly acted and beautifully directed, this is a bewitching tale that will stay with you long after you leave the cinema. One of the best films of the year.
Beautifully directed, visually stunning Western with terrific performances from Casey Affleck and Brad Pitt - this is one of the best films of the year.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Enchanted is an enjoyable comedy with several hilarious gags and a genuinely charming performance from Amy Adams. Worth seeing.
Stagey but enjoyable drama with superb performances from its two leads.
Engaging, impressively directed and ultimately devastating drama with strong performances and a powerful political message.
An engaging drama with superb performances, but it's slightly let down by an anti-climactic ending.
Quote not available.
Rendition is watchable enough thanks to decent direction and strong performances.
Easily one of the best films of the year.
Desperately unfunny, badly written sequel that's essentially a mish-mash of tired cliches, fart gags and genuinely terrible performances. One to avoid.
The script is rather bland, the action sequences are extremely dull and it lacks a big effects-heavy set-piece.
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Hugely enjoyable fantasy adventure with a witty script, strong comic performances, several wonderful gags and genuine chemistry between its two leads.
Enjoyable, sharply written and frequently hilarious comedy with strong comic performances from its cast. This should strike a chord with slightly overweight men everywhere.
Impressively directed, gripping thriller with a strong script and superb performances from Watts and Mortensen.
A delicious delight from start to finish, with a terrific script, great performances, sumptuous animation and a non-stop barrage of wonderful gags, both verbal and visual.

Resident Evil: Extinction does exactly what you'd expect from a threequel - it's not especially scary or witty but if you want hot chicks kicking zombie arse then it delivers enough action to keep the Friday night crowd happy.
The performances are excellent.
Enjoyable, frequently hilarious horror comedy, although it's stronger on laughs and gloopy gore effects than it is on actual scares.
With a terrific cast and a superb script, this is a hugely enjoyable suspense thriller of the sort that they really don't make anymore.
Berman and Pulcini's comedy drama isn't as funny or as clever as it thinks it is, but it remains watchable thanks to strong performances from Laura Linney and Scarlett Johansson.
Impressively directed with superb special effects, this is an action-packed fantasy flick that's actually more fun than the first film.
Enjoyably schlocky horror flick, with its tongue firmly in cheek, ensuring that there are several laughs to be had amidst all the gory, hatchet-wielding mayhem.
With a wide-ranging array of interviewees and an amusingly Moore-like approach to its subject, Manufacturing Dissent is an enjoyable documentary, whether you're pro-Moore, anti-Moore or indifferent.
Watchable drama with superb performances from a strong cast, though it ultimately feels too self-indulgent to be emotionally engaging.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Absurdly gung-ho but no less enjoyable thriller, providing you don't take the flag-waving politics too seriously.
Enjoyable comedy with several big laughs, though it runs out of steam way before the end and is badly let down by a messy final act.
Hirschbiegel's troubled remake has several good scenes and is by no means a disaster but it's ultimately disappointing thanks to poor editing and clumsy writing.
Something of a disappointment, due to a poorly conceived script and an underdeveloped plot.
Impressively directed, beautifully photographed and superbly adapted drama with terrific performances from its cast.
Year of the Dog isn't quite the comedy it's been marketed as, but there's still a lot to chew on here, notably Molly Shannon's performance as a woman on the verge of a nervous breakdown.
Hugely enjoyable action flick that delivers likeable characters, a decent plot, plenty of wisecracks and more breathtakingly ridiculous stunts than you'll know what to do with.
Flawed but enjoyable adaptation with some good ideas balanced against occasionally amateurish direction and unintentionally amusing pronunciation.
Worth seeing for Imelda Staunton and the impressive effects' work but it frequently feels rushed and lacks the drama and excitement of the previous two films.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Enjoyable, frequently amusing and surprisingly romantic French romp with a witty script, superb performances and a subtle message about the value of comedy.
Poorly written, badly directed and ultimately scare-free horror flick that's further hindered by dismal performances and unintentionally laughable dialogue.
Quote not available.
Enjoyable, stylishly directed thriller with a gripping plot and superb performances from Gosling and Hopkins.
Overlong, over-plotted and frequently dull threequel that only really gets into gear in the last forty minutes thanks to an impressively action-packed climax.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A badly written, poorly directed and appallingly acted mess.
This is a well-made sequel but the violence is extremely sickening and it's not nearly as much fun as the first film.
Uninspired threequel, though the animation is better than ever and there's a steady stream of chuckles, even if it does lack the magic of the previous films.
Quote not available.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Engaging, impressively directed and superbly acted drama that succeeds as both an inspirational sports flick and a darkly observed study of mental illness.
Below average, overlong drama that fails to deliver an emotional punch, largely because it's unsure of whether it wants to be a father-son drama or a romcom.
The film unfolds at a leisurely pace and takes the form of a series of incidents and anecdotes, which works surprisingly well.
Superbly directed, thoroughly engaging and emotionally moving biopic with a sensational, Oscar-worthy performance from Marion Cotillard.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Enjoyably trashy remake with a suitably creepy performance from Sean Bean, even if it's not quite on the level of Rutger Hauer's original.
Basically, the title says it all and if you're unlucky enough to end up seeing this, you'll be repeating that title for the entire 96 minutes. Avoid.
Quote not available.
Average comedy-drama that's not as moving or as funny as it thinks it is, but remains watchable thanks to strong performances and likeable characters.
Better than the disastrous sequel.
Enjoyable, well made family drama with strong performances, an engaging plot, impressive action sequences and a decent script.
Gripping, powerful documentary with a terrific soundtrack and a compelling narrative that resonates on both a personal and political level.
Brilliantly written, superbly acted and achingly funny, this is a terrifically entertaining musical that will have you grinning from ear to ear throughout.
Quote not available.
Death Sentence seesaws wildly between being both brilliant and terrible, but ultimately it's worth seeing for some terrific action sequences and Bacon's committed performance.
Enjoyable, slow-burning thriller with an intelligent script and strong performances from its two leads.
Impressively directed drama from the director of Young Adam, featuring a superb performance from Jamie Bell and a terrific soundtrack.
Enjoyable chiller with some terrific suspense scenes and a superb performance from John Cusack.
Disappointing, undercooked romcom that falls flat due to the lack of chemistry between the two leads and is only livened up by Abigail Breslin's performance.
Extremely funny, well written and sharply observed comedy with strong comic performances from its talented cast.
Watchable, energetically directed thriller that doesn't quite come together, despite decent performances from Mackintosh and Walters.
Enjoyable, frequently tense and superbly directed chase thriller with strong performances and spectacular photography throughout.
Engaging, strikingly photographed and packing a powerful emotional punch, Lady Chatterley is an award winning drama with terrific performances from its three leads.
Quote not available.
This is a sweet-natured, extremely funny romcom that marks Waititi out as a talent to watch. Highly recommended.
A dull and uninspiring film, despite Harris' best efforts.
Brilliantly written, superbly acted and hysterically funny, this is easily one of the best films of the year.
A satisfying conclusion to an excellent trilogy, The Bourne Ultimatum is an exciting, intelligent and impeccably directed thriller.
An ambitious but largely successful attempt to marry Bollywood and Hollywood, Marigold is worth seeing for Ali Larter's performance and some joyous musical numbers.
Disappointing threequel that lacks the spark of the previous two films and resorts to grafting dreadful jokes and lacklustre action sequences onto a nonsensical plot.
Dismal comedy that's every bit as bad as the words Robin Williams plays a comedy priest might lead you to expect.
Enjoyable, superbly animated comedy with likeable characters and an original approach to the story.
Sharply written, sweetly acted indie drama that's laced with an extra layer of sadness due to the tragic death of writer-director Adrienne Shelly.
Slow-moving, badly acted and painfully pretentious drama that fails to engage on any level.
Something of a disappointment, given Studio Ghibli's track record, although Le Guin fans can probably go ahead and add an extra star.
