Impressively directed, sharply written and superbly acted, this is an emotionally engaging samurai drama that builds to a thrilling climactic showdown lasting a full 45 minutes.

Watchable but ultimately disappointing documentary that's let down by some severe structural problems, a lack of focus in the editing, too many characters, an oddly flat finale and a curious refusal to explore or contextualise the central subject.
Priest is stylishly conceived and has the odd decent action sequence but it's also derivative, curiously flat and neither as scary nor as much fun as it should have been.
Watchable, handsomely shot Depression-era drama with strong performances from Witherspoon and Waltz...
Pacey, excitingly directed mini-Bourne-style thriller with a strong script, superb action sequences, a great soundtrack and a terrific central performance from Saoirse Ronan.
Sharply written and astutely directed, this is an enjoyable, frequently funny comedy with likeable characters and great comic performances from a superb cast.

Gritty and effective, this is an impressively directed British thriller that cleverly mixes several different elements and ultimately succeeds thanks to a mesmerising central performance from rising star Toby Kebbell.
As a showcase for her work the film is extremely impressive and the 3D technology is put to spectacular use.

Delivers pretty much everything you could want from a Thor movie, thanks to a superb script, note-perfect direction from Kenneth Branagh, a terrific supporting cast and a charismatic, star-making central performance from Chris Hemsworth.

It proceeds at a dour and Russian kind of pace, mildly intriguing without ever cranking up the pressure to become compelling.
Impressively directed and beautifully shot, this is a superb documentary that's by turns thrilling, heart-breaking, jaw-dropping and laugh-out-loud funny...
Fails to convince on every level, thanks to an ironically charisma-free performance from Alex Pettyfer.
Turns out to work surprisingly well, thanks to likeable comic performances and a script that's at least consistently amusing, if never laugh-out-loud funny.
A huge letdown.

Impressively directed and beautifully designed, this is a highly entertaining and frequently funny action-adventure romp with a witty script, great special effects and a terrific central performance from rising star Louise Bourgoin.
movie_title: Les aventures extraordinaires d'Adèle Blanc-Sec (The Extraordinary Adventures of Adèle Blanc-Sec) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Well made, powerfully moving and genuinely inspirational documentary that shows the astonishing ripple effect of an act of charity.

Red Hill starts brilliantly but tails off halfway through and fails to deliver on its initial promise, despite a strong performance from Ryan Kwanten.
This is a powerful and depressingly downbeat drama that is often hard to watch, although the inexpressive nature of the main character means that it's difficult to fully engage on an emotional level.

Ultimately disappointing, thanks to largely unlikeable characters and an unwillingness to commit to the full-on nastiness required by the plot.

Watchable collection of prison movie clichés, enlivened by strong performances and pacey direction.

Painfully unfunny sequel that desperately tries to recapture the magic formula of the original film with increasingly tedious results.

Well acted, effectively creepy in places and lifted by some impressively inventive direction, even if it's occasionally repetitive and over-reliant on cheap shocks.

Arthur provides some overly mannered narration via a journal he's been keeping, but that also offers few clues to how much of what we're seeing is real or imagined.
The performances feel natural, improvised, and it's easy to believe this is the world we inhabit.

I'm sure Roland Emmerich had the best intentions creating his own version of the Stonewall riots, but the movie itself is a total slog and doesn't give proper due to the actual riots.

While Hotel Transylvania 2 is a visual marvel, it doesn't come anywhere close to the originality of the first movie. The story is weaker, the laughs are infrequent, and you can feel the movie's desperate attempts to seem hip.
Beasts of No Nation isn't the type of movie you "enjoy," but it is extremely effective in depicting one boy's harrowing journey into the heart of war.
As with most anthology films, some shorts are stronger than others, but there are definitely a few standouts.
While the film isn't without a few tonal flaws, the performances -- particularly Robbie's -- keep the story grounded in a sublime, post-apocalyptic reality.
The Last Witch Hunter delivers a lackluster fantasy plot and bland, one-note characters.
The greatest thing about Hail, Caesar! is that its loose structure allows the Coens to just mess around with the things they like.
Adam McKay's The Big Short plays like an elaborate con, albeit one that uses its powers for good.
Some of Tarantino's worst instincts are on display in The Hateful Eight, which -- damnit! -- could've been so great.
[A] grueling but engrossing tale of survival and revenge in the American frontier.
If only How to Be Single had the smarts to not just deliver twists on clichés, but avoid them altogether.
This is old-fashioned, corny filmmaking, with all of the emotional beats and crescendos you would expect.
Never has the impossible glamour of Cate Blanchett been used to better effect than in Todd Hayne's ravishing and romantic Carol.
Makes American Sniper look positively pacifist by comparison.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's sturdy, watchable, competently mounted, of course -- Howard is nothing if not a pro -- but except for the visuals, which can be quite stunning, it never roused me.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: One more thing about Pete's Dragon: You will cry. A lot.

I am a huge Jennifer Lawrence fan -- I think she is an intuitive and smart actress -- and it's great that she's been given a part this meaty to sink her teeth into. And I get why Russell cast her... But boy oh boy, is she miscast.
Corny as it was, I cried when the men were rescued.
Brooklyn is the very essence of a simple story, beautifully told.
Not only did I love every silly, gothic, gorgeous minute of Guillermo del Toro's Crimson Peak, I'm actually suspicious of those who didn't.

The Jobs here will always be "Aaron Sorkin's Jobs"... who people say was nerdier and more youthfully exuberant than the fully in-control maestro depicted in the film. But Fassbender does a great job with what he's given.

Diesel is definitely not the kind of actor who can effortlessly coast through a film by dint of his rakish wit and charm. He needs a vehicle (ahem) that plays to his strengths. The Last Witch Hunter is definitely not such a vehicle.
Room can be, at times, an almost unbearably emotional experience, but that's a good thing. It feels good to feel so much at the movies.
Mostly, I thought Burnt was ridiculous. And yet I cannot tell a lie. Its familiar beats, comely cast, and lively kitchen montages entertained me.
One of the most unnecessary sequels of all time (yes, I've seen Speed 2).
It's a formula film, executed to near perfection. And it wields a secret weapon: our nostalgia for the original.
Linklater has audaciously made a movie about our most maligned subset of young men -- bros -- and forced us to admit that we actually like them.

It gives me no pleasure to trash this film. I want D.C. Comics fans to have nice things, too. On the bright side, there are, like, a gajillion more D.C. Comics films coming down the pike. At least one of them has to be good, right? Right?
It's a wonderfully immersive adventure. Come to think of it, I don't want to know how they made those creatures come to life. Why ruin the magic?
Against the odds, Florence Foster Jenkins manages to be a funny and even endearing film. But I kept asking myself, what's it really about?

Don't Think Twice is about the creeping realization that you might not live up to that dreaded thing called potential or that the mythical big break might never come your way. It's also about learning to be okay with that.
It's the kind of compulsively watchable film you'll be helpless to resist when it shows up on cable TV.
Like the wine Bobby opens on his first real date with Vonnie, it just needed some time to breathe.
On its own terms, Bad Moms is also pretty good. But its view of motherhood feels downright retro.
If you're buying what these filmmakers are selling, you'll be all in. Suffice it to say, I wasn't buying it.
Is this a film about grief masquerading as a horror film -- or vice versa?
The new Ghostbusters is a blast, certainly as much fun and funny as the original.
Beyond a few ingenious touches here and there, The Secret Life of Pets is a fairly standard kiddie caper that borrows heavily from Toy Story with an A-list voice cast and some top-flight animation.
Being a Pixar film it is, of course, eye-poppingly rich with color and detail. (The glowy underwater light of the film is particularly breathtaking).
The BFG does a bang-up job with its titular hero -- and for that alone, I can recommend it. I simply wish its human heroine had been treated with similar care.

There is, indeed, some wonderful art direction here. But watching Jesse stare in the mirror for the umpteenth time or repose with glamorous ennui on one of those divans, I found myself rolling my eyes.
It's a fairly shallow, formulaic love story -- albeit it one that is slickly told.
There is so much more, but part of the (perverse) pleasure of The Lobster is how it keeps you off guard, never lets you feel settled.
A Bigger Splash is a film to be savored, especially if you're able to appreciate its slow and sensuous rhythms.
Crowe and Gosling have a wonderful, gruff chemistry here, which is key. If this is the beginning of a Lethal Weapon style franchise for the two actors, count me in.
It's funny and warm and gives us Sarandon's great performance.
Sing Street is a shaggy, uneven, but undeniably endearing and entertaining film, especially if this was the music of your childhood, as it was mine.
It's this light-heartedness that keeps Captain America: Civil War from succumbing to the kind of pretentiousness that marred Batman V. Superman.

Both Winstead and Gallagher Jr. are great as the young bomb shelter roomies, but it's Goodman's film. He's a Stephen King-style character -- affable and menacing, with both a cheery bonhomie and a hair-trigger temper.

I have no idea if the science in The Martian is accurate. It sure felt accurate, which is all that matters in a way. On top of being wildly entertaining, the film is about using your wits to overcome seemingly insurmountable odds.
Spotlight is acted and directed with great urgency -- and a little bit of necessary dread.
Yes, it's a relief to see Depp playing a real character again, not another one of his circus freaks -- I just wish he'd been given a better film to operate in.
Star Wars: The Force Awakens honors the series and takes it in exciting new directions. Both The Millennium Falcon and millennials, it would seem, are in good hands.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Trainwreck is a complete blast. Even as it sends up rom-com clichés, it manages to be both seriously funny and genuinely romantic.
Ant-Man is a surprisingly nimble, enjoyable origin story with a little-guy-saves-the-day quality that will particularly appeal to younger viewers.
Kapadia's documentary -- which uses home video, archival footage, and clips of concerts and old and new interviews -- feels a bit like a horror film, except the inescapable monster is fame.
It's kind of facile and kind of corny, but I don't know... kind of important, too.
Magic Mike XXL sort of plays like the lesser sequel to the movie we all thought the original would be.
Rachel's dying isn't really about Rachel at all. It's about Greg. In fact, everything that happens in the film is about Greg.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: How a sweet story about a boy and his dog turns into a lame thriller about backwoods weapons dealing is anyone's guess.
Inside Out, which is co-directed by Pete Docter and Ronaldo Del Carmen, may be [Pixar's] most inventive film yet.
Love & Mercy is one of the most convincing depictions of the creative process and the effects of mental illness I've seen in a long time.
The whole thing is an elaborate fantasy, so it seems a bit churlish to say, "that's not believable!" But even a film like this needs some internal logic.

Spy is many things: A clever spoof. A chance for Melissa McCarthy and her co-stars to strut their comedic chops. An international romp. It's also a pretty darn engaging spy film. It's about a woman leaning in and finding her inner Bond.
There's not much I can say about it, except it demonstrates a staggering lack of creativity -- it plays exactly like an extended episode from the later years of the show.
Half the time while watching Aloha, I had no clue what was going on. Not so much the plot -- although I was admittedly a bit muddled on that, too -- but why anyone acted the way they did.
All the moving parts are expertly juggled by director Brad Peyton and, yes, the special effects are impressive. But the disaster stuff is laid on way too thick.
Say what you will about the film's wielding of stereotypes -- it genuinely loves its characters.
I wish -- oh how I wish -- it was a little bit better than it is.
Yeah, I get it. I admired the film a lot. But did I love it? Well...
To borrow the film's parlance: It never stops not stopping being funny.
The thing that's particularly galling about his latest installment, The Choice, is that the script seems to think it delivers a sophisticated and witty battle of the sexes.
Everest's uncanny realism is a big part of what keeps you in its icy thrall.
As horror films go, the film is more slow burn than an edge-of-your-seat thriller, but it builds steadily to its dreadful and earned conclusion.
The movie Mother's Day is so godawful, it doesn't just give the titular holiday a bad name, it might actually give mothers a bad name.
99 Homes is worth seeing, especially for the urgent, raw work by both the actors and Bahrani, and for what it says about the American economy.
Just the mechanics of getting to the roof are fun -- filled with surprise allies and strokes of luck and last minute escapes.
Darned if the film didn't ultimately work for me. Mostly, it was the fun of seeing these two veteran actors riff off each other.
Here, [Shyamalan] loosened up, shed some of his ego, and reminded all of us what a gifted writer and director he truly is.
You'll be happy to meet the strong, smart -- and yes -- unapologetically horny teenage Minnie and, for two hours, be immersed in her world.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Efron is a natural and likeable presence on screen and has proven to be a pretty decent actor in films like Hairspray and The Paperboy. But the problem with "regularness" is that, in the wrong hands, it's kind of dull.
[In the second half,] Baumbach is able to turn his loving gaze away from Gerwig long enough to let his actors shine and allow us to enjoy all the mayhem.
The best thing about Grandma, other than Tomlin's furious and funny performance, is that Elle never gets too cuddly.
Almost obscenely entertaining.
I enjoyed The Man from U.N.C.L.E well enough, and I suspect you will, too.

The backdrop of Rodney King-era L.A and the realness and rawness of N.W.A.'s music, not to mention the passionate and heartfelt performances of the film's three young leads gives the film an undeniable power.

I can't speak to its veracity, but I loved Segel's work here, playing Wallace as someone who over-analyzed everything, to a compulsive, near paralyzing degree, while still managing to be the most interesting, literary guy in the room.

If Jason Bourne is our most brooding spy and James Bond is our suavest, then IMF agent Ethan Hunt is our most intense, the one most willing to do whatever it takes to get the job done. Sound like anyone we know?
Streep makes us care about Ricki even when she's being a stubborn jerk. It's another astonishing performance by her, in a film just good enough to deserve it.

I like everything about Paper Towns except for its premise and central romance. Yes, I know those sort of seem like dealbreakers, but the things I liked about Paper Towns marginally outweighed the things I didn't like. Marginally.
About as subtle as a right uppercut to the jaw, Southpaw is nonetheless a welcome addition to the boxing melodrama genre.
You will leave this film remembering that Joan Rivers is one very funny woman (albeit a vulgar one). You will also see her as a woman of great strength, a true show biz survivor.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: [London Has Fallen] is atrocious -- wildly implausible, casually racist, mean-spirited, and strangely defensive about U.S. drone strikes that take out innocent civilians in the Middle East.
Look, I love Melissa McCarthy -- she is a truly gifted comic actress -- and I want to love her films. So she should stop making bad ones! It's bumming me out!
I wish I could tell you more, but honestly it's all just a blur of pretentious speeches about what lurks in the hearts of men and noisy fight scenes and nonsensical dream sequences.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Everything in this film, from the voiceover narration, to the familiar rock 'n' roll and Sinatra musical cues, to the freeze frames, to the tale of reckless and ambitious young men behaving badly, seems lifted directly from the Scorsese playbook.
Daniel Craig recently said that he'd rather "kill himself" than do another Bond film -- and in Spectre, his misery shows.
Indignation may indeed be the best of the Roth adaptations, but it also illustrates just how difficult adapting Roth can be.
But while It is a good film that is skilled at recreating its milieu, it also made me a little sad. Boys get all the good nostalgia pieces.
The cast is stellar-Ingrid is, objectively, a horrible person, but we feel for her anyway.
Remember how panicked we all were when Soderbergh said he was retiring a few years back? Thank the film gods, there's always one last heist.
With Good Time, the Safdie brothers have flaunted their gritty bona fides.
Bigelow is too talented a director to make a film this unsubtle. Detroit is a classic of example of: Just because you can do something, that doesn't mean you should.
Landline is warm and observant, gently funny and moving. And sometimes, as the film argues, cozy and familiar is exactly what you need.
The sneaky genius of Amanda Lipitz's documentary Step is how it manages to tell an important story-in the form of a triumphant "Big Game" narrative.
Atomic Blonde is less a movie than a mood. But if you're in the mood for what it has on offer, you'll emerge one happy camper.

The movie is about a group of old college friends who take off for a long overdue girls' weekend in New Orleans, but, thanks to the smart script and Lee's slick direction, we're emotionally invested in each of their journeys.

It's hard to quantify the audacity it took for David Lowery to make this film. It's a ghost story, a haunting meditation on life, loss, and mankind's place in the universe, that features a man under a sheet with the eye holes poked out.
Valerian is frenetic, trippy, ludicrous fun. Except for when it's not fun. But then it's fun again! And then not fun! Well...you get the picture.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A fitfully successful exploration of anorexia that plays like a slightly above-average TV movie.
In a time when prestige TV is hogging lots of attention (and deservedly so!), Christopher Nolan's stunning WWII saga makes a pretty strong case for the continued sustenance of film.

So yeah, I liked Spider-Man: Homecoming. I laughed during the funny parts, felt moved during the moving parts, and got excited during the exciting parts. And that Tom Holland -- he seems like a good kid.
All the characters are flawed but sympathetic-the film has a true generosity of spirit.
It may not end up being my favorite film of the year, but I can easily see it being someone's favorite-hell, I can see it being someone's favorite film of all time. It's that special.

It's a wild ride, a highly caffeinated tour de force filled with great action, lots of deadpan humor, and the kind of prevailing coolness that makes you want to drink espresso, troll vintage record stores, and watch old Steve McQueen films when it's over.
I can't quite say I enjoyed it, but I'm not going to forget it that easily, either.
It's clear that [Sofia Coppola] has been itching to make a gothic film and she luxuriates in the genre.
I can't conceive of a more boring character to revolve your franchise around than Mitch Rapp.
Haley gave Elliott the gift of this career-defining role and Elliott returns the favor by giving a career-best performance.
mother! is a film that demands to be seen and reckoned with.
It's hard not to like Victoria & Abdul-but it's all shiny surfaces. I can't help but to wonder how much deeper Frears might've dug into this rich material had he directed it 20 years ago.
Mackenzie happens to be Scottish, but he's made the best American Western in years.
It's impossible to not cheer for the message of A Wrinkle in Time-But those messages should be conveyed organically, through plot and character. Here, they have all the subtlety of a promoted tweet.
Finally, we are freed of this franchise.
Cooper is something of a master of macho poetry-he makes films about taciturn, often violent men who can't fully express the depths of their feelings.
It's almost impossible to describe Paul Thomas Anderson's Phantom Thread without using words like "sublime" and "ravishing" and "rapturous."

[I, Tonya] wants to show the abuse, but suggest that it maaaybe didn't happen that way. To have fun with Tonya and her grotesque mother and her husband's dim-witted friends and then judge us for judging them.
All in all, I was seduced by this film. It's a gripping suspense thriller and a fabulous portrait of the bottomless nature of greed.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Despite all its pain, love is always worth it, the film argues-and makes you believe.
The Shape of Water is whimsical, boldly original, defiantly weird, occasionally grotesque, and beautifully shot...yet, despite all of that, the film didn't quite work for me.
If you're still open to [Woodie Allen] as an important American artist, this is definitely one to put on your list.

The Disaster Artist should definitely first be seen in the theater, with a raucous crowd roaring with laughter. But later it should be seen at home where you can also observe the film's sneaky empathy and grace.

Despite my reservations, Three Billboards Outside of Ebbing, Missouri is certainly memorably clever and boldly conceived. And any film that allows McDormand to strut her to stuff to this degree can't be all bad.
Exploring the resilient spirit and dark underbelly of the Jim Crow South, Dee Rees has created a new American classic.
If Gerwig's cinematic brand is going to be tenderness, feminism, spiky humor, and empathy, count me in.
The whole cast is great. When you have Idris Elba in a relatively minor role of the all-seeing protector Heimdall, you know your ensemble is stacked.
Quite simply, one of the best films about childhood ever made.
Only the Brave is essentially a war film, with brave commanders and earnest (and not so earnest) young men who love each other fighting a menacing and relentless enemy.
Marshall isn't particularly interested in going deep on Thurgood Marshall the man-it's more about the Marshall, the myth. That said, what it is is just fine.
On its own merits, Blade Runner 2049 is a very strong film; as a sequel, it's nothing short of brilliant.
With its genius cast, wonderfully calibrated emotional and comic beats, and brilliant 70s mimesis, Battle of the Sexes is slick, commercial filmmaking at its best.

I didn't believe a single moment of The Book of Henry. Despite the best efforts of the cast, I laughed when I was supposed to cry and resented the hell out of the film's force fed "life lessons." It's just a good old fashioned stinker.
I loved spending a couple of hours in the Black Panther's magical, transformative world. Mark me down as someone who wants Wakanda to stay isolated.
Unlike lots of comic book movies, it feels like a work of passion and vision. I sense a filmmaker behind it, not a focus group.
Chilling and essential.
Slow-paced and methodical, filled with arresting long shots.
Lane's loose, playful, collage-like treatment of the story sets just the right tone.
Ira Sachs is a director of uncommon empathy and insight. His latest explores the perils of gentrification and the wisdom of the young.
La La Land is hopeful, even giddy. And Chazelle directs with heaps of style and charm.
The creators of Miss Sloane probably never imagined that their cynical film would seem downright quaint. Life comes at you fast.
Kenneth Lonergan's Manchester By the Sea is the best film I've seen in 2016. But I'm honestly not sure I can watch it again.
In the hands director Taika Waititi, who mixes sentimentality with spiky, even absurdist humor, it's a remarkable treat.
The performances here are stellar.

It's easy to say that Denis Villeneuve's tingly sci-fi Arrival is a whole lot of Spielberg with a little bit of Tarkovsky thrown in, but what's remarkable is how much it actually defies the conventions of its genre.
Barry Jenkins' Moonlight is a deeply personal, deeply expressive film, unlike anything I've ever seen before.
Man, I thought most of this film was a load of hooey -- right down to Garfield's tremulous, moist-eyed performance and that sing-songy cornpoke accent of his.
Is McGregor a bad director? Lord knows he's not the first to swing and whiff at Roth. I'll give him a mulligan here.
As Christian, Affleck is a mixed bag. Sometimes he plays him with an appropriately affectless and reticent quality. Other times, he can't resist letting loose a bit of his Affleck charm.

The rebellion itself is brutally violent, cathartic, and terrifying. In the end, it becomes clear that this is not one of Tarantino's florid revenge fantasies, but a true story of the men and women who were willing to pay the ultimate price for freedom.
It's a grown-up thriller that convincingly makes the case that true patriots hold their government to a higher standard.
In short, Bridget Jones's Baby is not a great Bridget Jones movie, but it is a Bridget Jones movie, and maybe that's all people need.
[Hanks] is predictably great, especially in a scene where he's informed that all his passengers survived, but it's a quiet, dignified performance, the kind that has lately become his stock-in-trade.

Suffice it so say that director Roger Michall keeps us guessing the whole time. See the film in a crowded theater and enjoy not just the gorgeous settings but the shared fun of delighting in Philip's folly.

A Monster Calls is a fairytale about the bogusness of fairytales -- about the reality of unhappy endings and the darkness and light that lives within us all. Guess your kid has to learn about existentialism eventually, right?
Not all so-called passion projects are able to convey actual passion on screen. This one does. Silence feels like both an ardent reaffirmation of faith and a lonely cry out to God in the dark.
I enjoyed this scrappy little movie, the second consecutive one to feature a female heroine.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: While I appreciate that the film contains multitudes -- and, yes, maybe even the spark of genius -- I must confess that I'm not fully down with the hype.
Most of the "jokes," such as they were, have a mean-spirited edge and virtually none of them made me laugh.
On top of being entertaining, illuminating, and affecting, the film is beautifully shot -- with gorgeous, hazy light and painterly framing -- it looks like a narrative feature.
Snatched definitely has its fair share of laughs, but it could've been so much more.
There's that old expression-may you live in interesting times. Mills' addendum to that is: And may you be raised by interesting women.
I can't say that Rat Film is a cheery experience, but it's certainly an indelible one.
With a few false moves, the film could've been an embarrassment. Instead, it's nothing short of a triumph for all involved.
In the end, I think this film would've worked better with B-list actors and a director who fully embraced the melodrama. As it is, The Light Between Oceans feels like a film between genres.
Gifted may not have anything particularly enlightening to say about raising a precocious child, but as a tear jerker/crowd pleaser, it more than gets the job done.
The film is so inept, it starts with a teaser of sorts that basically spoils the whole film.
The action sequences are not among the series' best -- Fast Five remains the gold standard across the board -- but there are a few gems.

Watching it is akin to the experience of being trapped in a room with a Golden Retriever that is repeatedly licking you in the face. You'll emerge slightly happy, somewhat dazed, and covered in slobber.
The beauty of Kristen Stewart -- well, aside from her literal beauty, that is -- is that she can do almost nothing on camera and still be arresting.
The film is taut and scary; all the spaceship bells and whistles convinced this Luddite, and it contains a couple of the gnarliest death scenes I've seen on film in a while.

The film is certainly a spectacle -- so congratulations, Disney CGI wizards! And there's enough talent involved -- not to mention the good bones of the original story and music -- to make it more than watchable
Before I Fall is one of the more pleasant surprises of the year.
They should've called this one The Fifty Times I Yawned.
You come to Kong: Skull Island to see Kong and the film delivers. He is massive and fierce and formidable, but those moist eyes of his reveal his true sensitivity.
Get Out finds that sweet spot of laughs, chills, and social commentary. It's so flat-out entertaining, you might not even notice how scathing it really is.
The funny thing about John Wick: Chapter 2 is that it's the exact same movie as John Wick: Chapter 1-- and yet somehow manages to work almost as well.
Despite its flaws, The Zookeeper's Wife is the kind of handsomely-mounted melodrama that will inspire many to bemoan the fact that they don't make them like this anymore.
Sad, funny, human and true.
Utterly bizarre and heroically dull.

Unfortunately, having created this original and interestingly stylised universe, Anderson frustratingly fails to put it to any better use than to tell his story in the safest, most obviously calculating manner possible.
Different enough from Tarantino's previous work to finally win over even an inveterate Tarantino-sceptic like me.
Ghost World, like the best of Ozu's cinema, has captured the shadow of time passing.
An impressive demonstration of cinema's ability to tackle complex ethical and philosophical issues without forgetting to entertain.
Despite the achingly raw performances and formal inventiveness, Heaven Knows What struggles as a piece of gripping cinema.
Sadly, Stephen Frears gets the balance wrong with his latest film, with the result that neither the gags nor the heartfelt moments come off as intended.
Its imagery and mysticism have by no means lost their power to astound.
A valuable record of a movement whose boldness still has the capacity to impress.
movie_title: Troublemakers: The Story of Land Art (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Mon Roi is one of the best films of the year and an impressively realistic depiction of the highs and lows of love.
This is no heavy-handed tale of Western decadence versus pure indigenous wisdom, with Guerra constantly emphasising the ambiguous relationship between the two.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Despite a promising concept and strong production values, Summertime's poor execution makes it one to avoid.
The wishy-washy execution means it is unlikely to win over anyone who doesn't already agree.
Masterfully balances its personal and political concerns.

The only saving graces are the (admittedly excellent) cinematography and production values -- the action scenes are crisp, smooth and packed with tension -- but they feel almost irrelevant when the content they have to work with is this bad.
An eclectic combination of reenactment, voiceover recollection and contemporary newsreel footage.
20th Century Women speaks to the ultimate inscrutability of each and every human being.
Icaros achieves this hallucinatory effect through its top-notch cinematography, special effects and soundscape.
Ai Weiwei might be best known for his sculptures and installations, but with Human Flow he has created a masterpiece that truly captures the humanity at the heart of the global refugee crisis.
Both Morcsányi and Borbély play their roles to near perfection.
movie_title: On Body and Soul (A Teströl és Lélekröl) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: As a viewer one certainly leaves Insyriated with a more visceral understanding of what the Syrian conflict means for millions of families. Whether that is of any help to them, is a separate question.
New Year celebrations have only recently been and gone, but it may well prove difficult to find a more perfect film than Paul Thomas Anderson's Phantom Thread in 2018.
Journey's End deserves commendation for its refusal to descend into melodrama; this is not nostalgic period drama, but an unvarnished depiction of organised murder.
Hoover's documentary is full of stimulating ideas and observations.
As a movie of any sort, it's entirely self-serving and exists solely to cash in on audiences desperate for any sort of horror film fix.
Under no circumstances would I call Inherent Vice a bad film. It's too weird and fascinating and filled with too many delightful performances...
Despite cramming in numerous clichés, Mehta still manages to put a fresh and funny spin on the proceedings.
This is not a conventional political documentary. Yet there is something politically valuable, even radical, about asserting the potential of a mode of possibility -- of a perhaps.

Jackie, the first English-language film by Chilean director Pablo Larraín, offers a compellingly uneasy and nuanced portrait of one of the best-known first ladies in American history, engagingly played by Natalie Portman.
Revelling in ambiguities and uncertainties, the film not only invites us to puzzle out its mysteries, but also asks us to explore the very source of our unease.
Brooklyn is about more than choosing between lads. This is about choosing between fates in an era of newly won independence.
Spotlight tells a crucial story of morals that still resonates amid continued injustices.

The Stonewall Riots were a triumph for a marginalized community, but Emmerich fails to convey the significance of the event in any meaningful fashion. The subject matter deserves better, and so do we.
At the end of the day, it works and is worth your entertainment bucks. And that's really saying a lot.
The narrative is gripping, the music score uplifting, the screenplay tight enough to allow for very few slippages.
Leave aside jokes running on the Internet. This film, just a few feet too long, is fine entertainment by itself.
Would this movie have the same impact on the young as did Anand's incredible Hum for the generation before? No. Would this Agneepath suffice still? Yes.
Intentions apart, this is exasperating entertainment.
This is the sort of movie you'll take home with a smile and a song on your lips.

Between the action sequences, one-liners, songs, and Salman making an entry in slo-mo in almost every scene, anything else you may hear about this critic-proof flick is of unnecessary academic interest alone.
Most jokes fall flat. Except when directed at Bollywood itself.
Everything appears so visibly constructed and all over the place that you gape at the wires, rather than blend in with the experience.
Mad stuff!
The picture promises to never end.

Few actors in mainstream films manage a self-assured, under-stated swagger, convey so much silently, sometimes just with their glance and droopy eyes... Bachchan perfected it as the 'angry young man'. Devgn, you can tell, is his fine successor.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Mumbai (2010)

movie_review_blurb: What you take home are memorable, amusing moments of three truly adventurous amigos we've all grown up with.
Somewhere the crispness of the dialogue and comic timing is lost.
Sure, this movie's a risk. Shouldn't each be anyway?
The jokes, you can tell, have pretty much dried up. No amount of slapstick will wet this pool.
This is a very different kinda Balki movie...does it manage to entertain? Absolutely, if you're patient enough through the first half.
Unlike the Bhatts' recent hits, the premise of this film is neither clear nor newsy...the plot isn't quite borrowed either. So this film is largely original. And that is a big problem.

The producer confuses his own generosity with the number of humongous sets and holiday destinations he can send his team out to shoot songs. The only ones suffering are we. Really, I don't know a worse shortcut to excess.
It's astounding how many scenes short can a movie this long be. The hero and the alien suddenly are in love. And you know how that love will show.
Each shot is worth a photograph in frame. Bhansali is no doubt an aesthete. His imagination is evidently a massive indoor dream on a palette that consistency changes colour tones with every film.
The relatability and realism of it all, despite the hasty simplicities in the plot, add much to the character.
As an idea, this remains still a full-on film festival designed around the female lead. She is decent. She usually is. But, what is this film?
movie_title: Dil Bole Hadippa! (My Heart Goes Hooray!) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Golmaal 2 (second-rate stuff) apparently raked in big bucks. Such success can boost anyone's over-confidence.

Mukkabaaz marks Kashyap's fab return to a realm he understands and expresses best -- with all its flaws, angst and humour, Tarantino-esque pop-culture references, making it all as distressing as it is frickin' fun and real.
[Browning] dominates the screen, even when unconscious, and somehow manages to convey a painful fragility and raw underlying strength.
There comes a point where you can't decide whether you're bored or nauseous, or a little bit of both.

It's definitely possible to quibble about the sheer ridiculousness of Conroy's situation a day or so down the line, but while you're watching it you'll be too busy hiding behind your shirt and nibbling on your collar to even think that far ahead.

Like a catchy political pop song, Made In Dagenham sneaks in a crafty punch, bringing through messages of strength through unity, class consciousness, friendship across social boundaries and, of course, equality of the sexes.
It's visually stunning from beginning to end, with the opening and closing moments in particular being (quite literally) breathtaking.
There's a sense of inevitability about things, certainly, but it seems less written in the stars than unhappily scratched onto the kerb with a flicknife by John himself.
The closing reels make up a fight scene even Quentin Tarantino would have thought too one-sided for Uma and her second-hand yellow jumpsuit in Kill Bill.
Yes, it's very, very silly, but The Skin I Live In is also hell of a lot of fun.
If pandas spawned as successfully as hit movies, they'd be off the endangered list in no time.
So devoid of spark and humour that no matter how loud or fast or yoof it gets, it still feels like an endless slog.
It does have the odd cheeky nod for the grown-ups -- and it is presented in inglorious 3D -- but it's also got a screenplay overflowing with charm, intelligence, wit and a real spark.
Sugar might look like a typical underdog sports movie on the surface, but over the running time it transforms into something much more interesting.

There's the rare occasion where the boldness of the dialogue is laid on a little thick and it drags you out of the moment, but it doesn't happen often, and the odd excess is more than forgiveable given just how well the rest of the film works.
A gritty low-budget mix of some of the best bits from Mad Max, Outbreak and Night Of The Living Dead, it ticks all the boxes in a refreshingly snappy 84 minute runtime.
Along with the uniformly fine performances, what makes Ondine really worth the trip to your nearest arthouse cinema is its wonderful charm, which it has in bucketloads.

If there really is a fine line between stupid and clever, this is so far to one side that it makes it look like a dot. If you take the time to check in your brain when getting your popcorn though, you'll probably be too busy laughing to mind.
Where Thank You For Smoking was perhaps too madcap and Juno too wordy, Up In The Air perfectly combines witty dialogue and set-pieces with real emotional connectivity from all three leads.
The music sequences themselves are faultless, with Serkis's performances (recorded with the real-life Blockheads), adding the sense of physicality that lip-synching always dilutes.

What might sound on paper like heavy-handed flick that tries to shove clever-clever ideas down your throat is nothing of the sort. Cold Souls is funny, thought-provoking, often witty and always boasts a tremendous lightness of touch.
Colin easily transcends its origins to rightly take its place as one of the better British horror films of the past few years.
Pandorum is neither schlocky enough to be an enjoyable genre flick, nor smart enough to provoke any original thoughts.

The strength of the script and the direction throughout is surpassed by the skill of all the lead performers, and especially Jarvis, who elevates what would have been a good film to something very special indeed.
It's not only the heavily-signposted "secret" that's obvious, but every single scene, as square pegs fit joylessly into square holes for the full running time.

The problem with Antichrist is not that it is bloody or attention-seeking, though it is clearly both. It is that from a thought-provoking premise it says absolutely nothing about grief, its two protagonists or the human condition.
Like Meek himself, Telstar draws you in despite its its imperfections, which don't detract too much from a bold take on an undertold and fascinating story.
A calm, sometimes heartbreaking, tender ode to love.
You have been warned.
Shrek Forever After is a fairy tale ending for the series.
All too often [the film] borrows from the ideas and conventions of the pysch-horror without giving either them, or the audience, enough respect for it to work.

Hudgens is a likeable on-screen presence, Olsen a complete riot, and Pettyfer teases teeny bits of a performance as a genuinely unpleasant baddie that could be the making of him one day, should the right script come along.

Like all the best sci-fi, Arrival isn't really about aliens. It's about people. It's about ideas. But instead of hammering you over the head with those ideas in a bid to show how clever-clever it is, the film lets the story and characters do the talking.
You get an insight into teenage life, but the ideas and emotions are subtle enough to enhance and not overshadow the story.
Here and there we get the microscopic and cosmic in fractal harmony and it's all sorts of lovely. It doesn't happen enough.
Pieced together in a fittingly arch, self-conscious style that fits Cave like a dark black glove.
By not foolishly trying to tell The Whole Story, Habicht has done so much more.
movie_title: Pulp: a Film About Life, Death & Supermarkets (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Morrissey 25: Live lacks the spark or the edge that would make this a real cinema experience...
Soundtracked by an impossible reunion, Made of Stone sticks two fingers up at the cynics and reminds us that your first love is the deepest and that real friendship never dies.
movie_title: The Stone Roses: Made of Stone (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Up there with No Direction Home and The Filth and the Fury, Marley is one of the greatest ever historical music documentaries.

The naturalistic performances from the three leads make the fantastic seem possible for a middle portion which could otherwise have spun out of control, and they're definitely helped by the in-your-face reality of the format.
You Instead is a really charming film which captures all the magic and mud of the perfect festival experience.
It's all good fun.
At the end there's the humorous promise of sequels, but if Machete is a neat, bloody full-stop on the mainstream Mexploitation genre Rodriguez has done so much to resurrect, it's a fine one.
Despite its flaws, this movie feels necessary.
If the desire is to unsettle and disorientate, the movie succeeds, but it does so at the expense of pretty much all else.
What lets Womb down is its slow-to-the-point-of-complete-tedium pacing (especially in the first half), and finicky way it's stuck together.
Many people leave. We stay end. Not sure why.
The swashbuckling Guise, kindly Count, raging Philippe and swaggering Duke make the two-hours-plus runtime fly by.
movie_title: La princesse de Montpensier (The Princess of Montpensier) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Steady but slightly lacking.
Bardem and Iñárritu draw you in to a story that says so much about not only its individual characters but also of life, exile, love, family and death.
The cast is the main draw here, but it's also the movie's biggest problem. Hopkins and Jones are excellent, and a greater focus on that couple might well have resulted in a much better film.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: What saves the flick is Paul Giamatti's John, played as a petulant, damaged man born in a world where he wields the power of a god and inevitably rages as that power is snatched away.
Outrage is equal measures gangland power struggle and broad comedic farce, all shook up with a fizzy hit of ultraviolent set pieces.
Where it completely fails is when the in-your-face amorality is contextualised with an icky epilogue which tries to justify what came before as some kind of "spiritual journey". It doesn't convince.
To its immense credit, Howl the movie makes a huge success of this potentially problematic mish-mash.
If this was a tiny bit smarter (think Desperado, or even Kill Bill Vol. 1) or a whole lot dumber (Machete), it would be so much nearer to hitting its target.
There's still plenty of gorgeous eye-candy to keep adults going if they've taken their kids along for some unthreatening entertainment.
With the honourable exception of a film-saving Byung-sik, the characters are too unpleasant and two-dimensional to keep it together.
Born To Be Blue accepts the huge difficulty in accurately depicting a life, and doesn't make the attempt. The style is the star, more than any of the film's versions of Chet Baker.
The film generates fear and mistrust with very little in the way of effects, gore or outright scares.

The film's essential good nature and abundant charm may be best demonstrated by its pretty backwash of '80s-influenced electro-pop on the soundtrack and gently mocking cameos by Geena Davis and Scott Bakula.

Although the end is predictable, the movie skips done-to-death sequences, replacing it with a cartoon strip. A wise move we must say. Chitthi's high point is its innocent humour which makes it a one-time watch.

Summits that elusive Pinnacle of Stupidity -- the one where a bad film crosses some indefinable event horizon of moronics and becomes weirdly awesome. You may find yourself laughing harder at State of the Union than at any comedy you see this year.

As the story takes some surprising turns, it works like a slow infection: Patient audience members may find themselves awakening to the story in much the same way the characters awaken to their own capacities for tenderness.
A really bad movie about a really important subject is twice the artistic crime -- because, however well-intentioned, it trivializes human suffering while squandering a teaching opportunity.
McConaughey and Zahn's casual interplay makes the film.
It's a beautiful, slightly devastating parable.
movie_title: Postmen in the Mountains (Nashan naren nagou) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Terry is, in short, a great role for any actress. And Allen, who isn't just any actress, rips into it with the relish of a woman looking to reinvent her career.
An uneven but moderately entertaining comedy that plays largely on the strengths of Mac's comic timing.
A mild disaster.
The film works a slow magic.
The result is a tough but frightened guy -- someone who can kick down a door, then burst into tears when he finds a dead body inside. Willis isn't playing a hero; he's playing a man.
Imagine Ordinary People with half its IQ deducted.
Makes Agent Cody Banks 2: Destination London look like a Bond film.
It's gorgeous and strange, but Miyazaki's later films cover the same ground with greater refinement.
movie_title: Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind (Kaze no tani no Naushika) (1985)

movie_review_blurb: Tries to be every single movie ever made all at once, leaving the viewer with the emotional equivalent of whiplash.
movie_title: Diary of a Mad Black Woman (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Making gorgeous use of grimy tunnels, writer-director Nimrod Antal frustrates expectations in the best possible sense.
The result feels like a happy memory tainted by regret.
Its biggest problem is that Blade himself takes a back seat to a host of new and mostly uninteresting characters.
It's all so well-paced and cool-looking and mordantly clever that you may forgive the film's transgressions.
A movie of utter inconsequence -- a cinematic Listerine Strip that evaporates from the brain before you even get your popcorn tub to the trash.
The film, written by Ari Schlossberg, is part of a larger, bothersome new wave of Hollywood hack work: Producers are wrapping their ham-fists around handsomely shot dread-and-twist endings.
A slightly better-made movie of the week.
Watch Topher Grace. If there's any cinematic justice, his work here will certify him as a comic leading man.
Like Big Trouble in Little China without the laughs.
Boring and fundamentally silly.
One of those rare movies that manages to be silly and cool and important all at once.
Rather than making a movie about Fat Albert, they've decided to make a movie that comments on the Fat Albert TV series.

Despite its occasional nods to flashy editing and pop scoring, Flight of the Phoenix ends up feeling like the sort of leisurely man's-man adventure movie you used to be able to catch on Sunday afternoon TV.
Sometimes trying a little less hard to be 'funny' can yield greater laughs when you're playing with the lightly macabre.
movie_title: Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Oldboy is startling and amazing -- a cinematic hammer to the skull.
As satire, it doesn't add up -- but it's an admirable, if dull, experiment.
There's a lot to love about The Beautiful Country.
The story and characters make no sense.
It's slight stuff, with several conflicts settled off-screen, but it's not without its low-key charms.
Beyond a couple of cool guns and one long, gory, clever first-person shot, Doom is something the video games have never been: dull.
In small doses, this looks kind of cool. For two hours, it's excruciating.
The scenes that work are really funny. But for every gag that flies there are at least one-and-a-half that don't.
The movie works as a smart B film.
De la Iglesia is a mercilessly agile talent, turning his department store into its own little film-noir cityscape, only with better lighting and perfume samples.
movie_title: The Perfect Crime (El Crimen Perfecto)(Crimen ferpecto) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: One of those movies that gets a couple of things exactly right.

When scenes, performances and even individual shots in Lord of War are considered alone, they're brilliant.

movie_review_blurb: Once in a great while -- usually late August -- a movie comes along that's so lame, it doesn't deserve a bad review. It deserves a war-crimes tribunal.

If you can look beyond the simple-minded Socratic political discourse, The Edukators reveals itself as warm, humane and sad.

After getting off to a decent, somewhat muted start, Skeleton Key just gets sillier and sillier and sillier until it's yet another one of those stupid, noisy thrillers where everyone's running around in a house, yelling and falling down.
The lack of condescension, the decent jokes and an absolutely terrific performance by Butcher make Saint Ralph an honest-to-God crowd-pleaser.
Dumb fun.
The movie is an incredible exercise in style, a real movie-lover's movie.
Bay's best and worst film.
Writer-director Craig Brewer's movie is sweaty, unpretty and powerfully alive.

This absurd romantic comedy, about a couple of thirtysomething rakes who sneak into bridal parties to meet women, is often laugh-out-loud funny, thanks to the considerable charms of its four leads and a few gleefully tasteless sex jokes.

A movie that never delivers on its premise; a movie that takes promising character dynamics and gullet-stuffs them with idiot dialogue; a movie that will alienate all but the wee and easily impressed with its frequent lurches into stupidity.
It's just another bland, junior-high-basketball riff on The Bad News Bears formula, one that takes every single dramatic cue from the underdog sports-movie playbook.
Fox and Terrio have made a quietly stunning debut here, mounting a fast, sad and often funny study of what 'carpe diem' really means.

Unnerving and quietly profound.

Like a pop song, Sisterhood contains mostly simple messages -- love yourself, love your sisters, learn from your mistakes, be brave. But they're good messages, wrapped in a sweet, well-acted and not-too-counterfeit package.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A definite crowd-pleaser and a perfectly fun night at the movies.
A weird, pretty film with a dumb script, a skilled cast and a good twist, plus one hot sex scene and one brilliant scene-chew by D'Arcy.
Yet another teens-versus- hillbillies slasher flick.
Embodies a certain brand of brooding outlaw cool that feels increasingly rare.
Good dumb fun.
Limp, implausible, unthrilling, unfunny and vaguely sleazy.
The kids are going to love it.
Works more often than it doesn't.

The movie is meringue-light, occasionally amusing, adequately animated and utterly forgettable.
Amazing-looking sequel to cult fave Pitch Black; unfortunately, the film's wrecked by a surprisingly weak, goofy script.

Well worth an evening invasion of the art house.
This goopy dramedy is unfunny, mentally bankrupt and makes parenthood look like a terrifying death sentence.

Oh, yes, New York belongs to the Olsen twins, not vice versa. There's enough self-love to fuel a Streisand film.
The film wins you over with its sweetness.
The proceedings have the same sort of essential sweetness that made Greek Wedding such a huge hit.
It actually makes the 1989 version (starring Dolph Lundgren) look pretty good by comparison.
The story makes absolutely no sense.

Don't go in expecting much and you'll have fun.
Works because of its little poetic moments and some killer casting.

In the hands of a more nuanced actor, David could have been a riveting character; but DMX's limited range means it's never clear why such a remorseless thug was seeking 'redemption' in the first place.
With its riotous blowhards, visual gags, inventive camera work and florid language played for laughs, Ladykillers slays.

Ends up being tedious.
Tense, bloody, funny and smart; lacks original's conscience, but it's still a surprisingly gritty remake.

Funny, handsomely shot and has some really creepy stuff involving reflections in mirrors -- but it's also packed with a few too many false scares, obvious red herrings and mayhem you can see coming from a mile away.
Fans of Viggo Mortensen's performance as Aragorn in The Lord of the Rings will find at least one thing to like about Hidalgo: The movie's a veritable Viggo-a-go-go.
A snore.
In what must have felt like an Oscar bid at the time, Ryan struts with a hip-thrusting ferocity that would bounce small children into walls, all while doing some funny voice acting.
Not a total waste of your serial-killer dollar.

The movie's dragged down by a droopy male lead, narration that would sound saccharine in a bad airport paperback, music the filmmakers lean on like a car horn and an insulting, inconsistent approach to elderly dementia.
A decidedly less exciting popcorn movie that tries to mix Indiana Jones, The Da Vinci Code and several strands of conspiracy theory in one blandly entertaining package.
The fights are more exciting, the effects more realistic, the characters deeper, the performances meatier, and the director's love of raw, unbridled cinematic geekery is positively unleashed.
Haythe's script suffers from what I like to call 'Apollo 13 Syndrome': It's great when it focuses on the major crisis, but not so hot when it shifts to the people on the ground.

Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason is an amiable enough sequel to Bridget Jones's Diary, but it also puts an exclamation point on the first film's biggest problem: Bridget Jones and Mark Darcy are a really boring couple.

movie_review_blurb: For fans of New Korean Cinema with strong stomachs for violence and melodrama, there's a lot to love.
movie_title: Tae Guk Gi: The Brotherhood of War (2004)

movie_review_blurb: At 115 minutes, this is the longest computer-animated cartoon ever, and the setup might test the patience of younger viewers. But what a payoff!
What makes Saw so awful is that it starts with a clever premise and then completely blows it.

Yes, the film jumps up and down on a high wire over the chasm separating Pretension and Art. But that's also a form of courage.
Anime fans, notorious lovers of high-tech eye candy that they are, will forgive the occasional tedium; the movie's simply too handsome to ignore.
We all know firefighters are heroes; show us the humans under the hats.
Enjoys the weird distinction of being one of the year's funniest comedies and one of the best zombie movies ever made.

movie_review_blurb: [An] over-conceived, over-edited, under-written perfume ad.

Among the lamest serial-killer movies ever made.

A handsome, intelligent film that feels as restrained as its protagonist -- a comic premise without many laughs, a thriller without many thrills.

Extremely dumb, sporadically funny wacky-camping comedy.

A shabby, joyless, 90-minute slab of 'advertainment' designed to sell booster packs for a popular trading-card game.
Gorgeous and entertaining.

movie_review_blurb: A dopey, confused production.
Terrific performance by Mezzogiorno grounds a lovely, if flawed, film.
Taken simply as a Will Smith Summer Blockbuster, I, Robot scores above average.
A complete piffle.
David makes little sense as a character.
A mild disaster.

Do yourself a favor. Rent My Bodyguard instead.
The computer-animated Horton is largely funny and faithful to the spirit of the Dr. Seuss book.

movie_review_blurb: In a marketplace that tends toward cranked-up action thrills, it's just nice to watch a level-headed crime movie aimed at actual grown-ups.

movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Untraceable is also relentlessly grim and dull, and runs afoul of all the pitfalls you find in movies in which people rely on computers to do their detecting.
Actually, one cast member doesn't even bother to phone it in: The once-charming Katie Holmes is stunningly horrible as a granola-head diabetic who lives in a trailer.
27 Dresses is stunningly dull. And Heigl, freed from the challenges of a Judd Apatow script, does little to distinguish herself from dozens of other actresses forgotten at the cineplex.
The filmmakers are so deadly earnest about the power of music and love and all that stuff, you just twiddle your thumbs waiting for the inevitable.
It's more than a thrilling horror exercise -- it's a master class in this sort of filmmaking, nailing the fundamentals at nearly every turn.
It gives me no pleasure to report that the [Richard] Pimentel biopic Music Within plays like a well-intentioned TV movie.

On a basic-premise level, Forgetting Sarah Marshall sounds like any number of rom-coms. But Segel and director Nicholas Stoller go to the trouble of making the little details funny and filthy, and they have fun messing with the formula.

While [writer] Pinter contributes some venom-spitting new dialogue, he also deviates wildly from the original story in the third act -- which would be fine, if the deviations weren't less compelling and more abrupt than Shaffer's original ideas.

movie_review_blurb: There's really no nice way to put this: Trade wants to be the Traffic of sex slavery, and it fails at that task in ways that are alternately dreary, pretentious and vaguely sleazy.
Sydney is forgettable teenybopper flotsam -- but it's better than the usual teenybopper flotsam.
The movie has 'heart' in a way that doesn't feel cloying or dishonest. And the cast -- especially Janelle Schremmer -- just nails it.

Nicole Kidman and Daniel Craig are adequate leads, but no great actor will be more squandered this year than Jeffrey Wright, who does nothing but speak in vast paragraph blocks of exposition while looking haggard and bored.

A minor miracle in a summer full of weak, perfunctory or downright lousy 'threequels'. It's a relentless finale to the Bourne movie trilogy that raises the stakes, pumps up the action and develops old characters while introducing new villains.

The romance is boring. Everything is blandly good-looking. The emotional beats are so programmed, you can predict the entrance of every single note of the Philip Glass dirge of a score. And the title means nothing beyond its double-entendre.
...as an ADD overview of a deliriously trashy TV subgenre, this is a great start.
The movie's fine, but it's more safe than interesting.
Rise of the Silver Surfer is roughly 300 percent less cringe-inducing than its predecessor.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Georgia Rule is a comedy-drama about three generations of women learning to love one another in a small town. It's also an icky soap opera about these women coming to terms with a revelation of sex abuse.
30 Days of Night is a high-concept movie idea that's so good, I'm surprised we haven't seen it.
It's not horrible, but it's droopy, and it left me craving 30 Rock, with its vastly superior skewering of the privileged and self-involved. Fey should stick to writing her own material.
The movie's pretty good, occasionally very good. But I also kind of hope they don't make another one.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Imagine Funny Games stripped of all its social commentary, dark humor and information about its killers, and you're starting to get the idea. It's so spare, it's almost abstract.
