The funny and powerfully weird Rango is probably the closest I've seen a big-budget, computer-animated feature get to the comic vibe of my favorite Chuck Jones cartoons.

What makes Hood to Coast special is the way it sort of perversely captures the entire human comedy -- it's pain and pleasure tied up in sleep-deprived logistics, and the punchline is that the suffering is completely voluntary.

Yes, this is a very relative and qualified compliment, and yes, the snarksters will still find plenty to pick at, but this time around, even a complete demographic outsider like myself could at least vaguely comprehend the series' basic appeal.
Six films in, it almost feels like it's booting up a new-and-improved, darker, earthier, more grown-up and visually sophisticated trilogy.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Revenge of the Fallen almost feels like it's signaling an end-game for blockbuster movies: all sensation, no content, catastrophic expense.
Johnson doesn't just make it work: His confident direction takes what could have been self-consciously precious and makes it hugely entertaining and a little moving.
Go rent the one where Jason takes Manhattan, or something.
Hoffman just kills whenever Harvey owns up to his mediocrity and tiny failures. He and Thompson give this underwhelming story a genuinely human core.
The film is a minor Christmas miracle: It succeeds on its own terms, despite the gossip hounds' best blood-sniffing efforts, and dares to be an entertainment rather than a statement.
The movie gets just enough right that the things it doesn't get right (beyond its overdependence on a not-so-surprising story puzzle) smack you cold in the face.
The script is just all kinds of terrible.
Giving the performance of his life, largely in French, Van Damme delivers a soulful self-analysis.

While Bolt isn't as funny, memorable or inspired as the animation classic from which it pilfers, it's still beautifully animated, cleanly told, professionally voiced and makes you smile without insulting your intelligence.

The camera can only film the on-deck action from so many angles before it gets repetitive. The musical score is pabulum. Race technology and tactics are barely explored, and you never get a sense of the larger field of competitors.

Ultimately, if you think about it too hard, Bees is a movie in which a bunch of powerful African American women get their lives upended and in some cases destroyed so a little white girl can feel better about herself.
Maybe the real Ernie Davis really was this perfect, but the movie plays as if the filmmakers didn't want to offend his family.
What makes Wanted and Desired riveting is that Zenovich balances this immorality play by interviewing nearly everyone involved and mixes it with perfectly culled archival footage.
English seems to confuse empowerment with narcissism.
Unfortunately, the movie stumbles a fair bit.
Its subjects blandly keep your attention in almost the exact same way that reality-show contestants keep your attention.
Part of Smith and Berg's subvert-your-expectations game plan involves a major midfilm shocker, one that takes the movie to larger mythological places unrelated to Hancock's self-improvement quest.
Gunnin' for That #1 Spot is a basketball documentary where the climactic game looks like a Hong Kong wire-fu epic.
Bodrov has simply created an overwhelmingly awesome Khan who could believably conquer the overwhelmingly awesome landscape over the course of two more films.
The comedian really climbs out on this particular limb -- a limb so far from the tree, it might have given Peter Sellers pause.

[Director] Conrad seems to have used whatever clout he got from The Pursuit of Happyness to fund something personal and sincere -- a story that's ultimately about victories of character and suppressing your worst impulses.
Unfortunately, the film loses its merciless rage toward the end, devolving into a stock and broadly comic thriller about unpleasant people you never quite get to know.
You Don't Mess With the Zohan might actually be the stupidest movie with good intentions that I've ever seen.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Thanks to the documentarian also making his family the film's subject, Bra Boys feels more than a little like a violence-glorifying infomercial.
If anyone could take a movie about a bunch of jerks who play poker and make it interesting, it should be Curtis Hanson. Or rather, it should have been.
Surrounded by a strong cast, including Laura Dern as Peggy's insufferably protective sister-in-law, Shannon holds her own.
The movie offers very real pleasures. Reynolds has terrific chemistry with everyone, and watching him romance three of Hollywood's more intelligent, beguiling comediennes is a pleasure.

It gives me no pleasure to report that Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters is fairly excruciating to sit through -- because I'm writing this as a fan of the TV series that spawned the movie.
movie_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: ... smarter and funnier than it has any right to be.

When spoofs of bad singing and songwriting are the sharpest arrows in your quiver, and your politics are diluted until they hit about as hard as someone sticking their tongue out, your satire has a problem.

Despite the fact that Take the Lead gets the cliche-o-meter ticking like a Geiger counter at Hanford, the movie is very entertaining. The kids are gorgeous. The dancing's fun to watch. Banderas is compact and cool.
If you're considering a move to L.A. to pursue an acting career, this is your Scared Straight.
The Boys of Baraka leaves you outraged in the way only the best documentaries can.

It's ridiculous, over-the-top and as allegorical as The Warriors, in its own twisted way, only far more convoluted and darkly funny. And it's probably the year's first action movie spurred by actual, provocative ideas.
Freedomland is the worst kind of bad movie: one that thinks it's important.

It is -- almost two hours of people sitting around, staring at laptops and grunting, with occasional bursts of uninteresting violence that usually end with Harrison Ford falling down (or hitting someone with an appliance and then falling down).
Soul-quakingly lame.
The new footage adds almost nothing and feels like a lame, double-dipping cash-grab.
movie_title: What the Bleep!? Down the Rabbit Hole (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is gorgeous to look at, the script has a killer twist and the cast is competent.

Much like Nanny McPhee herself, the movie isn't pretty, but hiding underneath its gaudy exterior are a few worthwhile lessons, a gleefully morbid sense of humor and, best of all, an actual beating heart.
Nearly every gag is so soft, so sleepy, so utterly sitcom that it's hard to figure out who Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World is supposed to entertain, much less enlighten.
movie_title: Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, writer/director Richard Shepard's pinata-hued comedy tries a little too hard for quirk, right down to its 'funny' musical score.
It's horrible. It's wretched. It's Limburger pickled in castor oil.
... an intermittently funny but totally confused film that might as well be titled When Harry Met Oedipus.
The Ringer is appalling.
Jarrat's jolly-creepy performance might place Mick in the pantheon of great movie killers.

There's something quietly but unmistakably angry underneath all the slapstick. In its own crowd-pleasing way, Dick and Jane '05 wouldn't be out of place on a double-bill with Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room.
The Family Stone is almost totally emotionally bankrupt.
It's [Silverman's] hysterically wrongheaded standup persona, showcased in the one-woman show Jesus Is Magic, that's been twisting politically correct writers into descriptive knots.
Vastly entertaining, [if] slightly overlong.
There are some nicely over-the-top moments in this Battle Royale/Running Man puree -- most involving people plummeting and blowing up. But the misogyny and choppy action edits spoil the fun.
Scott, Sarsgaard and Clarkson are quietly ferocious with Lucas' mannered dialogue.
Unfortunately, the movie falls short of an "A" grade because director James Mangold and his co-writer Gil Dennis don't make you understand what Carter sees in Cash.
This is one of Downey's most enjoyable performances, and one of Kilmer's funniest.
Your children will probably love it, and you won't feel lobotomized in the process.
Derailed wants to be the mother of all moral-quandary thrillers, yet the film, while blessed with Cassel's sarcastic charisma and a few sharp moments, suffers from many crucial shortcomings.
You may find your own sense of hearing transformed by this global tour of the senses.

Yet another aggressively inoffensive family road-trip movie, only with Robin Williams in the Clark Griswold role, and it's pleasant and formulaic and nice looking without bothering to be terribly funny.
... while the film's blunter, more thrillerish and sadistic second half is less unnerving than its bloodless first, it still works as a smarter than usual cat-and-mouse death match.
After Kiss Kiss, Bang Bang, it's the year's second-best Christmas thriller.
You might be better off reading the book and imagining [Nick] Nolte as Socrates.
Blades doesn't hit the non sequitur heights of Anchorman or Talladega Nights, but the cast is great and several gags hit hard.

While the movie gets at a couple of truths about marriage, it's just not that funny. The pacing sags and the story-driven gags (including, ugh, a condom-buying scene where the clerk loudly discusses the purchase) don't sizzle.
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The Host is wildly entertaining; people who love the genre will get their geek buttons pushed hard by this flick. But what makes the movie an instant classic is that it's also, in its dark heart, a furious lampoon.
Seraphim isn't totally satisfying, even if you're prepared for an arty Western.
What kills 23 are any number of bad choices that render the movie tone-deaf, sometimes hilariously so.
If you're a fan of the show, you'll probably be a fan of the movie -- which mostly retains the Super Troopers-meets-Cops-by-way-of-Christopher-Guest-only-not-quite-as-funny vibe.
In Norbit, Murphy is back playing multiple roles. But this time the magic isn't there.
Catch and Release is an unfunny, undramatic comedy-drama that asks us to care about lying idiots making implausible choices.
A tame variation on the usual serial-killer art direction and a hilarious number of A-Team-style explosions in which no one is killed. It's offensively dull.
Often as not, the movie works. Here and there, it works kind of beautifully.
You have a the movie that feels like a video game: Faceless characters walk into a room, solve a crisis, then move to the next room. Rinse with seawater and repeat.
For all its charm, there's nothing in The Holiday you haven't seen in a dozen romantic comedies.
This is Fox's first release under its new youth label, 'Fox Atomic' -- and it makes me fear not for the children, but for what Fox executives think the children want to see.
It's entirely too straightforward and awestruck with itself.
Younger kids probably will dig Minors like we dug The Goonies.
The filmmakers behind the sweet-hearted, mostly well-made family film Flicka know their target audience. In fact, they cater to it at the expense of the original book.
As idiot car-crash movies go, Tokyo Drift is pretty fun, and certainly a more-than-decent entry in this franchise.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Owen Wilson seems (for a while) to be doing an Owen Wilson impression in You, Me and Dupree -- an odd, mild comedy about (are you ready?) a houseguest who won't leave.
[Writer/director] Miller's global harmonizing never feels preachy -- he's too busy cramming Happy Feet with enough entertainment for three movies.

Director Oliver Stone's surprisingly conventional 9/11 film acts as an inspirational counterpoint to United 93. There were many stories of courage that day, but Trade Center tells one of the few with an uplifting ending.
Diving into the merits of a movie where people are dodging snakes whipping through a depressurized cabin is a bit like trying to pick apart the subtext of Space Mountain.
The Protector is ridiculously fun to watch.
It's never quite laugh-out-loud funny. It doesn't wring enough out of its killer premise. It mildly squanders good actors.
Gridiron Gang feels less like a movie and more like a Tony Robbins motivational seminar.
The movie turns into an inspirational, uncomplicated biopic in which, yes, a series of awesomely violent fight scenes indicate that our worst enemy can be found between our ears.
movie_title: Jet Li's Fearless (Huo Yuan Jia) (Legend of a Fighter) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Heder's low-key, surprising charm and Thorton's gleeful wickedness at least glide the film in for a landing. You'll enjoy yourself.
Costner's strong performance lends the formula a little more weight than you might expect.
The writing is lazy, the movie focuses on all the wrong things and the tone lurches unpleasantly between gum-soft comedy and lukewarm thriller.
It's a gorgeous, strange little piece, but I did find myself wishing it poked fewer aces out its sleeve after urging us to pay such close attention.

The weak mystery story massages you into indifference, then tries to clock you with one fungo bat of a loopy twist that leaves you questioning not reality, but why you just spent 109 minutes trying to give a darn.
An unflinching examination of rape culture from a female perspective.
Victor begins and remains a cipher, leaving the movie little beyond unusual camera angles and confusing repetition.
Lucky Stiff shoots for "zany" and lands at "attention deficit disorder," but the songs aren't bad.
Gameau builds his case well, and by the end of the painfully dorky musical number, you may be swapping your smoothies for berries and plain, full-fat yogurt.
Big Sky masquerades as a psychological thriller, but underneath it's a meditation on the worthlessness of men.

Costa Rica is a beautiful place to film, and a woman's journey into wholeness can make for a fine story. But Feldman, having established all his stereotypes, refuses to push them beyond the motions you know they have to go through ...
Abbie Evans is a dynamo.
A Brave Heart raises the question: What makes a hero? What combination of bravery, ambition, and narcissism drives a person to advocacy on an international stage?
movie_title: A Brave Heart: The Lizzie Velasquez Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Maybe the film's website, where viewers are directed to actually learn about how to stop killing the planet, holds more answers than Racing Extinction itself.
Perhaps with allies who are relearning to fear God rather than their neighbors, the gun law reform movement stands a chance. The Armor of Light is keeping the faith.
A doc as vibrant as its auteur's mind, even as his body is rendered immobile.

Watching a teacher lead a group of schoolchildren around busy Bogotá on their little bikes, teaching them how to safely navigate their city on their own power, you might feel hopeful for the future of eco-friendly transportation.
It can be hard to take someone so pleased with himself seriously, but amid his grandstanding, Brand does offer some solutions to problems many of us rightfully feel are intractable.
Deschamps never ventures below the surface of Redzepi's wildly successful experiment, and while the pictures are pretty, no one judges food on appearance alone.
It ... exists in a candy-coated New York where everyone has infinite money, exactly six nonwhite people ever speak and Christmas is always gently covered with pristine, powdery snow.
The Boy From Geita has some fascinating subjects but absolutely no idea how to present them.
The film unspools in an unhurried manner, occasionally tugging hard at your heartstrings.
A suspense drama with a nail-biting finish, Drishyam holds the viewer by the eyeballs till its engaging climax.
The basic premise of Bangistan is interesting in itself.
While some scenes leave you scarred and teary-eyed, others don't even scratch the surface.
Saif is adept; Kat is pretty appealing.
It's a ham fest that is comparable to brain dead cinema of yore. The saving grace is, some smart one-liners and heartfelt performances.
What's sad is that the squabbles between the men and their girlfriends lose steam as they are grossly exaggerated, repititive and puerile.
Its failing is that it is told in an amateur fashion.
Writer-filmmaker Subhash Kapoor is one of the soundest story-tellers in Bollywood.
In his attempt to spoof destination weddings of the bankrupt and the famous, Vikas Bahl, (who also directed that gem, Queen) forgot to take a script along.
Pulkit and Yami breathe life into their characters. We wish they were not saddled with such a lacklustre script.

But most importantly, the film is an emotional journey that ties up all the loose ends between fathers and sons, whose ideologies may differ but who still share a deep bond that is impossible to shake off.
When Aamir Khan backs a film, you expect quality.
As far as performances go, Ray and Holly lead the way; Anupam Kher is adept and Kumail with his mostly-comic expressions passes muster.
Shabana is flawless. Aishwarya has made a judicious screen choice after that five-year hiatus.
The patriotic fervour in the climax brings a lump to the throat. If only the film had been 15 minutes shorter, the 'Jai Ho' would've resonated more.
Kamal's performance is A-grade.

Irrfan, Tisca and Tillotama give A-grade performances, making this film imminently watchable. If only the filmmaker had decided to buck the pace up for a bit, the points being made here would have hit home harder.
movie_title: Qissa: The Ghost Is A Lonely Traveller (2014)

movie_review_blurb: After Cocktail and Yeh Jaawani Hai Deeewani, Deepika is once again in superlative form.
Preity Zinta's maiden production has its aesthetics in place. Paris is enchanting. The actress is good but there ends the show.
Raanjhanaa is a love story that has a Shakespearean touch and is mounted on a lavish scale.
Full marks to the lead pair for not being overwhelmed by the commotion around them. Especially Hrithik, who knows the job at hand is silly, but never slips up.
Kangana Ranaut's performance is outstanding.
One mustn't grudge the filmmaker for telling us an old story. After all, in the last decade, not much has changed in the political landscape of India.
The story is not novel, but the treatment is A-grade.
Though there is a sense of deja-vu, for those who have read the book, the movie still manages to charm and surprise.

Leaving the plot open for a sequel, just in case Salman's fans demand one; ETT ends with telling you how Tiger's file went missing because, once this super-spy decided to go off the radar, no intelligence agency could actually track him down.
If you are looking for substance, then this one has no logic, only magic. But, if you're looking to just laugh and be merry, Golmaal will again do the trick.
Kiron Deohans's cinematography is ostentatious. The vibrant colours and images stay with you long after the lights come on. Dialogue writer K P Saxena comes up with some powerful lines.
If you average it out, Talaash is well worth the price of a ticket.
This is pure escapist fare but will resonate with those who read fairy tales at bedtime.
Want to tear your hair out in frustration? Wait, there's more to add to this convoluted screenplay.

Despite the disturbing backdrop of death, destruction and politics, Kai Po Che is very likeable. Between tears, you find yourself smiling, because it's the story of friendship and human triumph above all else.
The plot offers the viewer a whirlwind tour of scenic locations. But to what avail?
Let's give the devil his due, Imtiaz's films do coax and cajole you to take a journey inwards instead of just doing the peripheral one.
Shah Rukh Khan is the backbone of JTHJ. He's charismatic as the lover and enigmatic as the army guy. Katrina Kaif is a smart dresser and looks stunning.

Watch Bhoomi for Dutt. He's from that era of larger-than-life heroes who get you to applaud even when he turns a killing machine. You may not approve of his bloodlust, but you can't fault his swagger.
Rohit Shetty's films are big-ticket adventures; a genre unto themselves.
For an action thriller, the narrative pace is so languid, you can take your popcorn and pee break between the times when two bullets are fired.
The film doesn't take itself too seriously. So, you shouldn't either. Watch it for Nawaz.

Clearly, makers like Kaushik, who had a formidable box office record in the '90s remaking South Indian films, need to borrow modern-day technique and storytelling tactics to keep the ever-evolving viewer engaged.
The first half breezes through, but post interval proceedings hang.
All said and done, if you're up for something naughty, try Hunterrr.
One star in the rating is for Akshay who has mastered this genre. Riteish and Abhishek keep pace with him, as does Jacqueline. So if you just want to LOL-go for it.
These sequels are about erotica being served piping hot Bollywood style. So indulge in some guilt-free 'entertainment' and don't go looking for soul.
It is the fine display of histrionics by all these refined actors which makes the movie worth seeing.
Padmaavat is definitely worth a watch, for its scale, story-telling and stellar performances from the lead.

The highlight of the film is Hrithik's bravura performance. He is vulnerable as a lover and menacing as a killing-machine. Half a star in the movie-rating is reserved for his all-time best performance here.
There is enough pizzazz to divert you from the clichéd plot...the film belongs to Ranveer. He's as keyed up as an Energiser bunny, exuding charm and competence in equal measure.

Too many gags follow more gags, actors ham and situations get repeated. Wish the makers, who have invested so much in locations and item songs, had invested in a tighter screenplay because India is ready for a smart sex comedy.

AR Rahman lifts spirits with the club number Khalifa Khalifa and draws sighs with the poignant Alaahada. Armaan is endearing and energetic, getting you to warm up to him. Deeksha is confident and likeable.
It's basically innocent fun meant to pander to the child in you.

It is to the film's credit that though Geeta and Babita's wins are documented, it still manages to engage the viewer with the wrestling tournaments and bring patriotic emotions to the fore. Most importantly, Dangal scores with its first-rate performances.
If you like crime drama, Daddy is bound to fuel your imagination. Gawli is a part of India's crime-history. And this is the closest you will come to 'encountering' him.
The film's failing is its amateur writing and execution. You can see that the maker is crushed under the weight of the material chosen.
Emraan bears no physical resemblance to Azharruddin. However his mannerisms-the blinking of his eyes and swagger add to a knockout performance. Watch Azhar for him.
However, it falls flat because there is no chemistry between the lead pair. Bipasha is steamier when flirting with danger (read creature).
Feisty Alia, one of the better actors of the current generation, turns in a nicely nuanced performance. And SRK in his sober-avatar possessing infinite gyaan tempts you to seek out a therapist.
Zaveri takes his brain-dead audience for granted and unmindfully dishes out trite, leaving you angry and anguished.
Ki and Ka is worth a ticket because it shows how there is nothing wrong with the man wearing the apron and the women wearing her ambition.

As far as the viewer goes, the story dates back to the 60s, but when you catch the tributes paid to the the real Johnson, Vaughan, and Jackson during the credit roll, you know that this story of triumph needed to be told, right here, right now.
If you want that adrenaline rush of watching Akira beating baddies and punching holes into the system, go for it.
This is certainly not a classic like the yesteryear Casablanca, yet if story-telling and subtle performances do it for you, give it a shot.
Indian cinephiles must salute Rajamouli for his vision and ambition. He once again gives us our Ben Hur and Ten Commandments experience rolled into one.
If you're in the mood for some soppy, sentimental stuff, give this film a try.
If you're in a mood for some weekend cheer, Masterminds could do it for you.
Warning: Tarantino's cinema is not for the faint-hearted. However, the maker of Reservoir Dogs and Kill Bill, in his by now famous signature style, once again gives you substance to lose sleep over.

Nawazuddin's self-deprecating remarks and his seamless transformation from killer to lover is applause-worthy. Jatin Goswami's impresses; his lean frame and interesting voice lend to his screen appeal.
Bite into this barfi for sure; it is bound to lift your spirits.

Having the 11 women in one frame becomes nothing but a screech-fest. Having Vidya in a film is an asset though. She is an audacious actor, who merits an extra half star for her ability to shoulder a film.
This is certainly no Raging Bull. However, if you can invest in a boxer who is boisterous and bratty, Duran may hold your interest.
While Kal and the lovely Mischa, as the journalists on the rampage, have you rooting for them, Rajpal and Tannishta are nicely believable.
A tepid sci-fi thriller that takes an interesting premise and sacrifices ideas for the sake of logically challenged action beats.
Viewers who don't mind reading subtitles will be rewarded as they gradually get sucked in by the lush cinematography and a first-class, heartfelt story.
movie_title: Postmen in the Mountains (Nashan naren nagou) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A slice-of-life film that, while well-acted, isn't compelling enough to rise to a tale to which you'd want to give two hours of your undivided attention.
The only good acting is done by the sharks.

Not quite as good as the film made from another Ellroy novel, L.A. Confidential, The Black Dahlia is a stylish noir in the same vein, with rat-a-tat-tat hipster dialogue, tough guys, hoods, dirty cops, gangsters and molls.
Tthe gimmicks can't hold up a weak, implausible plot that substitutes violence and gore for a smart story and believable characters.
Scary Movie 4 piles on the gags rat-a-tat-tat style. Like clowns throwing cream pies, some hit their mark. Many miss.
Believable? Nah. But when a movie is this fun, who cares?

First Descent might become tedious for anyone wondering what all the fuss is about. But for those who have felt the thrill of carving an "S" down the side of a mountain on a snowboard, this movie is cheaper than a lift ticket.

The film picks up steam as the tunnel nears completion -- thanks, in part, to a Hollywood film crew that pays for the rights to the tunnelers' story, providing them with the money to finish the project.
There are a few cinematic hairballs along the way, but most of the film is a great ride.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Unless audiences think Curtis scampering after a runaway ham is funny, they'll want to skip this Christmas movie instead.
Stylish but muddled movie.
An amusing film that won't disappoint fans of the long-running comic strip.
A well-done murder mystery.
Nia Vardalos' follow-up to her surprising mega-hit My Big Fat Greek Wedding won't disappoint her fans.
Haunting documentary.
movie_title: Tibet: Cry of the Snow Lion (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A fun film that celebrates the pluck of a group of women who aren't afraid to bare all for a calendar that most likely hangs in the front of car repair shops and not in the back.
Captures the infectious coolness of surfing.
Man of the Year is merely a Robin Williams stand-up routine wrapped in a limp script.
An entertaining, sentimental film.
Turistas has better production values than most Hollywood pretty-people-in-peril movies. But even beautiful scenery can't gussy up this flat film.
Stealth is a widescreen video game, except all the audience can do is watch instead of grabbing a joystick and playing along.
An uneven comedy about a milquetoast named Norbit who marries Rasputia, a woman so large she'd start a fire if she wore corduroy pants.
Hamilton's life is already uplifting; there's no need to add more melodrama.
An unvarnished and unwavering look at 21st-century combat.
It turns out that wasn't a smile on Flipper's face.
It's charming, with gorgeous, painterly animation and a heartfelt story.
Tedious.
Eagle Eye skillfully taps into post-Sept. 11 paranoia -- a briskly paced thriller that blinks at times but mostly keeps its focus.
Petit is such an ebullient guy it's hard not to get sucked into his high-wire antics.
How bombs like Meet Dave get the green light in Hollywood is a mystery.
In addition to having a lame script, Strength and Honor is saddled with characters that are not to be believed.
Leaves little time for plot but plenty of scenes of biker gangs tooling down desert roads, with close-ups of exhaust pipes, handlebars and black leather jackets.
Jimmy Carter Man From Plains shows a relatively unvarnished portrait of a man who's not afraid to take on his critics.
The film ultimately tells a powerful and little-known historical tale.
Engaging and illuminating.
They're stories of war that resonate with anyone who has ever been in a war zone, and they illustrate beautifully for those who have not seen battle, just what combat can do to a person's soul.
movie_title: America At A Crossroads: Operation Homecoming: Writing The Wartime Experience (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's when the movie veers away from the green felt that Lucky You slows interminably, and you're left wishing that the characters would just shuffle up and deal.
The movie's heart is in the right place. It's just that the route it travels to get there is so dull and unsurprising that you just want the trip to be over with.
It might have been just another humdrum children's film if not for Highmore, who brings the same charm he did in Charlie and the Chocolate Factory and Finding Neverland to this fun movie.
movie_title: Arthur and the Invisibles (Arthur and the Minimoys) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating, funny and moving documentary -- possibly the best screen exploration ever of the Apollo program.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Crusty characters, a bluegrass soundtrack and a dysfunctional family that could exist only in the minds of Hollywood screenwriters make this film more precious than real -- or funny.
As for a plot, the film is too busy piling up dead bodies to have much of one. And, with dialogue consisting almost entirely of movie poster tag lines, Shoot 'Em Up shoots blanks.
Wrinkle in Time has much love in its heart, in execution, the film's beat-to-beat narrative is a bit of a mess.
Offers a hazy and yet utterly striking impression of a resilient Icon; a brush with something vibrant, raw, and eternal.

It could be argued that the film's relaxed, meditative contentedness merely echoes that of the Napa region and its winemakers. But tonally, it's aggressively one-note, and for me, the lack of critical introspection is a sizable problem.
Privileged, self-obsessed, and unsympathetic, every character was purposefully unlikeable to the point it was used for humour.
As raucous as the flirtation is throughout, actual intimacy -- physical or otherwise -- is rendered with unflinching clarity.
Despite these larger themes and its overarching heart-on-sleeve intellectualism the film's comedy is what makes it truly shine.
Diving in and out of sincerity and sap, it seems really unsure of what it wants to do.
La La Land is not just a musical, but a musical that loves musicals.
It's messy and personal and real, and that's exactly what makes it great.
The character's bravado and outrageous persistence in the first film was funny, but the laughs in the sequel are more complex and instead come from what happens when you strip all that away.
The Boss Baby is the surreal, nightmarish creation of someone who has recently come off a high dose of hospital-grade painkillers.
On paper, this is dumb -- it's really, really dumb -- but on screen there's something weirdly satisfying to it.
I perfected my "regret" face roughly 25 minutes into this hot mess. Good night, and good luck.
Despite its grave themes (or perhaps because or them), The Bourne Supremacy is still supremely thrilling.
The Terminal manages to amuse, entertain, and inspire.
Sure, The Notebook's story of first love tends toward the histrionic and self-important. But if that's case, perhaps Cassavetes, like Shakespeare, simply knows how to give the people what they want.
More impressive, with a couple of minor exceptions, the storyline navigates expectations that it would carry themes of racial politics into the Marvel Cinematic Universe with grace and goodwill.
You have to wonder if the real Barry Seal was as likable as the new true-crime thriller, American Made, makes him out to be, or if it's simply Tom Cruise's toothy charisma that makes him seem so.
